story:
Our Story


The youth have been meeting together for over 15 years. We want a space the kids [(7th through 12th graders)] can call their own. A place where they can associate, and bring friends. We currently do not have a space. Our renovation consists of refurbishing the bottom of a school house located in Amesbury, MA. Right now, the space is crowded with old flooring, old couches, tacky paint, and moldy smells. We want to raise $13,000 dollars to put in new flooring, create a built-in stage, and add new couches, TV displays, and entertainment such as a foosball table. We are also going to be  kicking off the new space with a battle of he bands contest.


The Impact

Our goal is to reach out to the "at risk" kids in Amsbury, MA and to break the cycle of violence, drugs, and lack of education. Our hope is to build relationships using the arts to give them someone they can look up to and give them a hope for the future.  We also plan on using the space for our current youth group. This space would alow us to put on more events as well as give the kids a place where the can call there own.  If this project does not go forward the "at risk" would have no place where the could go where they could feel safe and they will fall into the same cycle that they have been living in their whole lives.


What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $13,000 This amount covers the cost of paint, flooring, Computer, stage, sound equipment, and Displays.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to give financially but still  want to help we could use help with volunteer labor over the summer
you can also let other people know about this project.
story_txt:
Our Story
The youth have been meeting together for over 15 years. We want a space the kids [(7th through 12th graders)] can call their own. A place where they can associate, and bring friends. We currently do not have a space. Our renovation consists of refurbishing the bottom of a school house located in Amesbury, MA. Right now, the space is crowded with old flooring, old couches, tacky paint, and moldy smells. We want to raise $13,000 dollars to put in new flooring, create a built-in stage, and add new couches, TV displays, and entertainment such as a foosball table. We are also going to be  kicking off the new space with a battle of he bands contest. 


The ImpactOur goal is to reach out to the "at risk" kids in Amsbury, MA and to break the cycle of violence, drugs, and lack of education. Our hope is to build relationships using the arts to give them someone they can look up to and give them a hope for the future.  We also plan on using the space for our current youth group. This space would alow us to put on more events as well as give the kids a place where the can call there own.  If this project does not go forward the "at risk" would have no place where the could go where they could feel safe and they will fall into the same cycle that they have been living in their whole lives. 

What We Need & What You Get
Our goal is to raise $13,000 This amount covers the cost of paint, flooring, Computer, stage, sound equipment, and Displays.


Other Ways You Can HelpIf you are unable to give financially but still  want to help we could use help with volunteer labor over the summeryou can also let other people know about this project.

story:
Greetings, I am Dr. Augustus William Jordan III. By trade I am an English and Humanities Professor at the College level currently working and residing in Atlanta, Georgia. However, I am not your average educator because I use various aspects of Popular Culture in order to reach and motivate my students.

     In this particular campaign "I Wear The Mask," I am raising money in order to fund a staff development trip to the 1st Global Conference: The Graphic Novel this September in Oxford, United Kingdom. At this conference, I am scheduled to present a paper called "The Spectacular Swaggerman" which entails my inspiration as a young African-American male through idenitifying with the Marvel Comics Icon, Spiderman. Although the character's alter ego is Caucasian, my research delves into numerous aspects which enhanced my interest in the adventures of this "household name" in literary fiction. In this conference, I will also observe and exchange ideas with other educators like myself who have an intense interest in comic books and/or graphic novels.

     What I feel this conference will do for me is allow me to share my experiences on Multi-modal education methods with those of various individuals from around the world. This type of education, I feel, is invaluable because it uses entertainment to increase various learning centers in the conceptuality of our youth. For example, my paper "Spectacular Swaggerman" delves into the Spiderman story motto, "With Great Power Comes Great Responsibility". Although this is a term that can be furthered into other genres without regard to entertainment, the fascination with comic books for a youth tends to make the learning experience fun as well.

     As a contributor, I feel that you will help me to further my knowledge of teaching using multimodal techniques as well as spread the knowledge of these skills to others from various continents of the world. What better way would there be to increase a pupil's knowledge than to make it entertaining.

     The funding needed for this project will mainly go towards my travel and lodging to the United Kingdom. Due to cuts in education, I have been unsuccesful at acquiring any funds from my employers under the category of staff development, so your funding would help me immensely.  In return I have various campaign perks which I feel will be greatly appreciated.

     Even if I do not reach my $2500 goal by the deadline, the funds raised in this campaign will again be used towards travel and lodging. However, should we exceed, the monetary goal, the better the experience of my trip will be for those in attendance, for example, upgraded multi-media resources. To get an idea of some of my other conferences in which I've presented, The Hawaii International Conference on Education of 2008 is the prefect example that can be seen on Youtube. Although the topic of my paper for that conference was "A Narrative Analysis in the Chosen Literary Works of the Rapper Nas," the presentation is the perfect example of a successful staff development trip funded by a secondary institution as well as a presentation using multi-modular education techniques. Unfortunately, due to budget cuts, all staff development funding has been eliminated at all of my institutions.

     Yes I realize that times are hard now friends, however, if you are in a position in which you cannot support me monetarily, vocal support for my cause would be fine. Spreading the word will definitely help me to raise my goal. However, if 100 of my close friends all donated $25, I could exceed my goal. Those of you who know me, realize that on Facebook alone, I have 1000 plus friends of which more than 75% I know personally. This is where my pen name "6 Degrees" comes from.  In closing, use the Indiegogog "share" tool to post the campaign on as many pages of your friends as possible. Also, thanks in advance for your help in any way shape or form that I receive it.

 

God Bless You!

 

Dr. Augustus William Jordan III

story:
My name is Bradley Carleton. I am hoping that my story might appeal to those of you who believe that nature heals the soul. Here is my story.

Nine years ago I accepted a challenge that would change my life. I began mentoring a young man near my home town here in Vermont. I had no idea the impact that one individual could have on another's life. The experience served to be a life altering catalyst for me.

I had always tried to do things "by me, for me, through me" and had failed so many times that I no longer took my dreams seriously. Recognizing that I could not seem to achieve "my" dreams, I began searching for my purpose. Through a lot of time spent outdoors, hunting, fishing and foraging, I learned that I have a gift for sharing my love of nature with others. Soon I figured out that my purpose was to serve others by sharing our connection to nature to heal our spirits.

I continued mentoring for the next eight years and eventually designed a curriculum of traditional outdoor pursuits, whereby my mentees could wage battle against their adolescent demons, and found that they all had one thing in common; "nature deficit disorder" as defined by Richard Louv in his book "Last Child in the Woods". These young men had all lacked a connection to nature.

Through hunting, fishing and the art of foraging it has been proven that our connection to nature develops respect, compassion and empathy, and without that connection, a child will often mature without those characteristics, or at the very least, have a poorly developed appreciation for life.

  

For the past eight years I have mentored six young men who lacked a male role model and struggled with social skills in their journey to manhood. I have seen such dramatic changes in these young men that I was driven to establish a non-profit organization (still in the process of getting tax-exempt status from the IRS) to raise funds for the program. Through Traditions Outdoor Mentoring.org, the educational arm of Sacred Hunter.org, we teach them to hunt, fish and forage and to learn respect and empathy for the resources that nurture their spirit.

 

I was recently contacted by one of our old mentees and was told that "more than any other person in his life, our mentoring relationship had the most impact on his life." He had gone from a gang candidate to a young responsible father holding down multiple jobs in accepting his responsibility for his choices. Another mentee is currently serving in the Marines in Afghanistan, and we are very proud of his desire to serve his country. One of our current mentees is learning grace and humility through the art of fly-fishing. All of the young men we've worked with have had profound life-changing shifts in their adolescent consciousness from self-involved to charitable, from angry anti-social behaviors to respectful, self-confident young men, from "takers" to "givers."

Our program has been tremendously successful because of the genuine concern of those who have been involved as mentors and assistants.

I enlisted a few friends who devote a lot of time and care to working with our at-risk boys, We brought John Lesher and Chris Thayer on to our Board of Directors in April and, along with my wife, Katie Carleton, we have grown a grass-roots program into a focused organization.

We recently accepted Randall Eaton, PhD, author of "The Sacred Hunt - Hunting as a Sacred Path" and "From Boys To Men of Heart - Hunting as a Rite of Passage" on to our Board of Directors and are very pleased to have Mr. Eaton as a guide and brother in our mission.

I am deeply committed to this path and am finding that when I pursue my authentic purpose, things naturally develop and grow.

Our next step is to raise enough money to fund our programs. We need funds for youth-sized equipment (youth-sized bow & arrow kits, fishing rods, waders, decoys, blinds, calls, clothing, etc). for our young men.

We are proud to be a Vermont corporation, and in honor of the independent nature of our state, we are offering some very special Vermont-made perks through our partner, Dakin Farms.

If you've never had real Vermont maple syrup, cob-smoked bacon or a Lumberjack Breakfast, here's your chance! We are offering several levels of perks and ALL of them represent the natural wonder and beauty that is Vermont. We are sure you will be pleased with the time-honored Vermont tradition of quality foods that Dakin Farms offers.

Note: We are not a tax-exempt organization (yet) so your donation will not be tax-deductible at this time. Hopefully our IRS form 1023 submission for tax-exempt status will return a favorable Letter of Determination in the next 6-9 months. Your donation will help us until that happens. 

Thank you for your consideration and please feel free to visit our Facebook pages, Sacred Hunter.org and Traditions Outdoor Mentoring.org and "like" us if you do!. Please feel free to visit our websites, Sacred Hunter.org and Traditions Outdoor Mentoring.org. 

Also, please, if you are an anti-hunter, be respectful and know that we practice spirituality in this program. This is about love, respect, compassion and learning to nurture our bodies with the animal spirits.  We all have the freedom to practice our own methods of connecting with our Higher Power.

story:
What is Helix? 

The Helix Project tells the story of the life, not the death, of the Jews of Eastern Europe. For too long, mainstream Jewish institutions have distilled the fascinating history of Jewish life to a handful of talking points: religion, Israel, Holocaust, and a vague emphasis on "maintaining Jewish identity." Helix wants to transform the way Jewish history is taught and perceived.

We bring a group of 12 university students to the historical heartland of Jewish life in Central and Eastern Europe for an expenses-paid three-week long immersion in cultural history to see how European Jewish life, contrary to the dominant story, was not a successive chain of miseries — but a millennium filled with creativity, joy, and vitality.

We start in LA with an intensive crash course in the languages, history, and culture of Eastern European Jewish life. The trip then moves to Europe, where students follow in the footsteps of Yiddish poets in Belarus, visit centers of Jewish political activism in Poland, and make a literary pilgrimage to Vilnius, the "Jerusalem of Lithuania."

Helix students take the lead in sharing their skills and knowledge—academic, artistic, and social—with the group, learn to facilitate discussion and to navigate exploration of new sites. Helix takes students out of the classroom and into the streets of the places that were recently home to the majority of the world’s Jewish population.

Helix is organized by Yiddishkayt, the trend-setting non-profit which has promoted Yiddish language and culture, and especially the values of cultural openness and compassion embodied in that culture, for the past two decades.

Why Helix is Unique

Over the past 60 years, the catastrophe of the Holocaust has understandably dominated our sense of how Jews lived in the world. University courses on Jewish culture focus overwhelmingly on despair and tragedy. The success of Holocaust education has highlighted a serious absence: students know about loss, but not what was lost. When Jewish culture is taught from its endpoints, the Holocaust is allowed to triumph over the memory of the vibrancy of Jewish life.
 
Helix is the only program that seeks to fight against this erasure by having students witness just how alive Jewish life once was, exploring the landscapes Jews called home and the cultural treasures produced there. Helix creates a fuller, more inclusive view of Jewish life and history.

Helix is open to students of all backgrounds and is committed to teaching Jewish culture in a world-historical context. 

Why Helix Needs Your Help

Helix believes in offering this life-changing educational experience to outstanding college students regardless of their financial situation. But three weeks of travel to and around Eastern Europe is expensive!

This year we are taking 12 students and need to cover all of their costs through fundraising. The cost for each student is approximately $6,000. Several universities, including UCLA, UC Berkeley, University of Wisconsin at Madison and the Johns Hopkins University, partially offset costs for five students traveling this summer. But we still need to fund several more and hope to raise money to pay for at least two students with this campaign. Your tax-deductible donations will go directly toward defraying on-the-ground travel costs for the Helixers.

We're looking to you, those who love Yiddish, value Eastern European history, and connect with Jewish culture, to help us give at least two incredible students an invaluable academic and personal experience. To thank you for supporting our trip we are offering a number of gifts. Check out our hip tote bags, coffee table book, and treasure trove of specialties from the countries we visit!

Thanks for considering supporting us with your tax-deductible contribution!
Even if we don’t meet our full goal, every dollar we raise directly helps us pay for the Helix. 

 

Helix is Already Making a Difference

Helix is devoted to training the next generation of scholars, community organizers, and artists.

Last year Helix launched its pilot with 6 students and you can hear one of those students, a prospective rabbinical student, talk about how her Helix experience changed her perspective in a video here. Another Helix participant, now applying to graduate programs in Jewish history, reported that before the trip his sense of Jewish identity had revolved around his relationship to the Holocaust and the breadth of his knowledge was dominated by the last 70 years of Jewish history. Helix, he said, revealed to him a previously unknown world of Jewish life. A world he was able to glimpse most personally and poignantly while visiting the Yiddish high school where his grandmother taught physics in the 1920s. And finally, you can hear a moving piece broadcast on Public Radio International's The World featuring a Helixer's experience visiting the village of her ancestors. 

Even if you can't support Helix financially, you can help by sharing our campaign with your friends and family.

Do you want to support Helix or know someone who would but can't donate online? Click here to request information and a way to donate by mail.

story:
Tae Kwon Do for The Kids, The Community and The Future

My name is Sharon Wheeler and I have lived in Chicago's 27th ward, the Near North community for over 18 years and I love the art of Tae Kwon Do.  My entire family participates in the practice of Tae Kwon Do.  My husband and two oldest boys age 14 and 13 are black belts and my youngest son age 7 is a brown belt.  I too have just earned my black belt after practicing for over four years under the instruction of Master Blair Sarkiss at the H.M.D. Academy of Tae Kwon Do in Chicago.

Our community is one of the nation's most diverse and we have seen many changes occur.  In our neighborhood where the Cabrini Green projects used to stand a Target Store is being built.  The landscape is changing, but the people are still here and trying to live together in harmony.  Many low income families live in section 8 and subsidized housing in the area. There are still invisible gang lines that prevent children from crossing Division Street and Clybourn Ave. to gain access to park facilities.  

Last year I began teaching an afterschool Tae Kwon Do program at the local elementary school where 97% of the student population qualifies for free lunch.  We met for two 10 week sessions twice a week where the kids learned Tae Kwon Do but also an understanding of how it makes us strong in our minds and emotions too.  Sixteen children succeeded in earning their yellow belts!  

Chicago Public Schools (CPS) slated this elementary school as one to be closed in it's campaign to save money.  The administration, parents, community and Alderman succeeded in saving their school.  We would like to build bonds beyond gang turf lines through Tae Kwon Do.  The kids should be able to relate to each other and see each other as friends and neighbors.

We would like an opportunity to continue this afterschool program for three semesters in the 2013-2014 school year.  Our goal is that the children can continue to gain rank and for more kids to experience the benefits gained from the practice of Tae Kwon Do. In addition, we would like to offer an afterschool program at a second elementary school that is located across the Gang line in an attempt to 'bridge the gap' of undersanding and foster peace with the children using Tae Kwon Do as a vehicle for shared experience.  

 

What We Need 

It costs (instructors and liability insurance) $10 per child per class.  We would like to be able to offer Tae Kwon Do to 20 children at each school.

Each school will have instruction for each semester (Fall, Winter, Spring) we will teach three 10 week sessions, two classes per week - 60 classes at each school - 120 classes in total. This cost equals $24,000.  We will donate the children's uniforms at a one time cost of $45 per child.

If we don't reach our goal we will still teach the afterschool programs although we will not be able to reach as many kids.

 

The Impact

The skills the children learn in after school Tae Kwon Do will carry over to their daily lives and help them handle all types of situations.  It will allow them to make good decisions in school, family and social situations.  We teach them what it takes to be successful and what integrity means, responsibiltiy, self discipline and why these traits are important.  

This program is about more than kicking and punching, it is about becoming a strong person physically, mentally and emotionally.  It provides lifelong skills in managing confrontation, improving school performance, and broadening his/her sense of accomplishment.  Tae Kwon Do will promote leadership and create a community of leaders that will create good will through the general population of their schools and hopefully create a new generation of youth whose goal is peace and understanding.

Tae Kwon Do for The Kids, The Community and The Future
My name is Sharon Wheeler and I have lived in Chicago's 27th ward, the Near North community for over 18 years and I love the art of Tae Kwon Do.  My entire family participates in the practice of Tae Kwon Do.  My husband and two oldest boys age 14 and 13 are black belts and my youngest son age 7 is a brown belt.  I too have just earned my black belt after practicing for over four years under the instruction of Master Blair Sarkiss at the H.M.D. Academy of Tae Kwon Do in Chicago.
Our community is one of the nation's most diverse and we have seen many changes occur.  In our neighborhood where the Cabrini Green projects used to stand a Target Store is being built.  The landscape is changing, but the people are still here and trying to live together in harmony.  Many low income families live in section 8 and subsidized housing in the area. There are still invisible gang lines that prevent children from crossing Division Street and Clybourn Ave. to gain access to park facilities.  
Last year I began teaching an afterschool Tae Kwon Do program at the local elementary school where 97% of the student population qualifies for free lunch.  We met for two 10 week sessions twice a week where the kids learned Tae Kwon Do but also an understanding of how it makes us strong in our minds and emotions too.  Sixteen children succeeded in earning their yellow belts!  
Chicago Public Schools (CPS) slated this elementary school as one to be closed in it's campaign to save money.  The administration, parents, community and Alderman succeeded in saving their school.  We would like to build bonds beyond gang turf lines through Tae Kwon Do.  The kids should be able to relate to each other and see each other as friends and neighbors.
We would like an opportunity to continue this afterschool program for three semesters in the 2013-2014 school year.  Our goal is that the children can continue to gain rank and for more kids to experience the benefits gained from the practice of Tae Kwon Do. In addition, we would like to offer an afterschool program at a second elementary school that is located across the Gang line in an attempt to 'bridge the gap' of undersanding and foster peace with the children using Tae Kwon Do as a vehicle for shared experience.  
 


What We Need 
It costs (instructors and liability insurance) $10 per child per class.  We would like to be able to offer Tae Kwon Do to 20 children at each school.
Each school will have instruction for each semester (Fall, Winter, Spring) we will teach three 10 week sessions, two classes per week - 60 classes at each school - 120 classes in total. This cost equals $24,000.  We will donate the children's uniforms at a one time cost of $45 per child.
If we don't reach our goal we will still teach the afterschool programs although we will not be able to reach as many kids.
 
The Impact


The skills the children learn in after school Tae Kwon Do will carry over to their daily lives and help them handle all types of situations.  It will allow them to make good decisions in school, family and social situations.  We teach them what it takes to be successful and what integrity means, responsibiltiy, self discipline and why these traits are important.  
This program is about more than kicking and punching, it is about becoming a strong person physically, mentally and emotionally.  It provides lifelong skills in managing confrontation, improving school performance, and broadening his/her sense of accomplishment.  Tae Kwon Do will promote leadership and create a community of leaders that will create good will through the general population of their schools and hopefully create a new generation of youth whose goal is peace and understanding.

story:
Why Gardens?
Because gardens produce healthier food. Only 2% of American children eat enough fruits and vegetables, and 1 in 3 American children born after 2000 is at risk for Type II diabetes. A garden is an introduction to the real, healthy food students and families need access to.

Because gardens can help fix America's nature deficit. With more than 80% of Americans living in cities and suburbs, we need to work harder than ever to teach the values of natural processes.

Because gardens are a living laboratory for education. Not just healthy food—a lesson on what producing healthy food requires. Not just exposure to nature—a way for children to literally harvest the fruits of their labor.

A True Seed Investment 
For as little as $10, you can help a community reap all the benefits a garden has to offer. In just 39 days, we plan to raise $2500 per garden; to feed,  teach, and inspire people in each of these 100 communities. Here are a few things our garden plans to do with your donations:

The Potrero Hill Learning Garden Project (PHLG) is an inclusive project, shaped by local community members to serve the whole community in a community garden space located in the diverse neighborhood of Potrero Hill, San Francisco. The mission of the PHLG Project is to strengthen community relationships between people of diverse generations, backgrounds and experience – with urban farming as a catalyst for growing community resiliency. Through educational programming rooted in regenerative strategies related to conserving energy, growing fresh food and supporting diversity, the garden becomes a living laboratory to inspire a positive outlook, new skills and interdependence on one another. As an outdoor classroom, the PHLG Project provides real life, hands-on activities designed to explore and engage youth and community members in health and nutrition, science, mathematics, ecology, agriculture, gardening and art. Through collaboration, experimentation, and education, we can connect youth to real-life solutions that empower and inspire them to become more resilient.

Garden Website: booka_alon@liveoaksf.org

CHECK OUT THE GALLERY FOR IMAGES & VIDEOS

Look Good, Do Good
With every contribution to our garden, donors will receive organic, ethical perks from PACT. Our socks, undies, and t-shirts are produced to high standards of sustainability, with the comfiest organic materials we can find. You'll be giving out of the goodness of your heart, and in returnyou'll get PACT goodies. It's a win-win situation.

story:
Short Summary

In a typical year more than 200 children move through the court system in Ohio, Marshall, Wetzel and Tyler Counties of West Virginia.  These children have been removed from their home through no fault of their own.  Their families are in crisis.  But the system is ill equipped to assure a child’s basic needs and rights are being protected. Too often a child can be placed in a different home from his sisters or brothers.  Too often a single child can move to three or five foster homes in merely a matter of a year or two.  Too often a child can languish for years without finding a stable home, only to ultimately “age out” of the system.

Our solution to such injustice begins with a single volunteer.  More than a mentor or a special buddy.  This volunteer is a Court Appointed Special Advocate, a “CASA volunteer.”  Someone specially trained to know what is in a child’s best interest, and how to get those interests met by the system.  Who knows how to help a child through his time of great vulnerability. A deeply committed adult.  A person who will fight for this child, against all odds, against power, against bureaucracy and shortsighted agendas.  Fight until that child understands that he has a right to believe in himself.  Fight, until she can understand and advocate for her own inalienable rights.  To live a life of destiny, rather than fate.


What We Need

CASA for Children Inc., a tax exempt non-profit agency is a volunteer based organization in Moundsville, West Virginia and serves four counties in the northern panhandle of West Virginia.  CASA has been advocating on behalf of abused and neglected children since 2001, in Ohio County and expanded in 2003 to Marshall County.  In 2010, CASA expanded again to Wetzel and Tyler Counties.

Our office operates with a full time director and one part-time volunteer coordinator. These 2 people recruit, train and supervise volunteers. CASA volunteers help the Judge determine permanent placement for a child.  If the child does not have an advocate this process can take a long time. The hope is that with a volunteer’s help, a decision about what is in the best interest of the child can be expedited, so as not to linger in the system for years.

The most important support we receive is our volunteers who devote time.  But we can still only reach around 70% of the kids in our community.  This robs children of the life they deserve, and has a profound impact on our community and society’s future.  If we help one child, we set a positive course for generations. Money raised would be used to offset the cost of recruitment, training and supervision of volunteers. We would be able to ensure that enough volunteers are trained to meet the need and that we can expand our volunteer base to reflect the diversity and cultural makeup of children in the system.  We would also be able to concentrate our efforts on creating a critical mass of support to put child advocacy where it rightfully belongs in our social conscience.

For the first time in 12 years, our program is looking at the very real possiblity that we may shut our doors.  That means 145 children without a CASA advocating for their needs. We are just 4 weeks away from closing down the center.  We need your support to keep our doors open until July 1 when our next grant cycle begins.  Federal and state grant dollars are being cut. Individual and corporate donations are more vital to our program.

The Impact

CASA is the solution.  A properly funded CASA program can make all the difference to a child.  CASA must continuously recruit volunteers to handle these cases.  Before being accepted into the program, volunteers must pass a stringent assessment and background checks, they then attend thirty hours of nationally accredited training before being sworn in before the Judge.  In addition, each sworn volunteer must fulfill 12 additional hours of training each year. 

During 2012, CASA staff and volunteers provided services to one hundred thirty children and provided the Court with reports recommending a variety of services for abused children and their families.  Our staff accompanied volunteers to more than 300 hearings this year. The Judges in our jurisdiction utilize the information learned from CASA volunteers to make important decisions in the lives of children. Because of CASA; 291 children have found their way to safe home.  CASA is the only program of its kind.  In the child welfare and family court systems, it was – and is – nothing short of a transformation.  Everything is built around one child and one compassionate, highly trained adult advocate for that child.

 When a child has a Court Appointed Special Advocate to speak for them:

• Time in dependent care is reduced
• Delinquency is less likely
• The Child has a better chance to bond with a permanent home.

If there is one characteristic that distinguishes the CASA organization, it would be ingenuity – that marriage of creativity and determination that makes just about anything possible.  It is why we have such a long history of doing more with less.  It’s why our track record is so good.  Sheer unabashed creativity and determination.  Driven as always, by doing whatever we have to for the children in our care.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please tell people about our campaign,and about our mission.
  • Become a CASA volunteer. Go to www.casaforchildren.org to find a program near you.
  • Remember you can use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you for taking the time to read about our program. Lift up a child's voice. A child's life.

Thank you for taking the time to read about our program. Lift up a child's voice. A child's life.

story:
Support our mission to get everyone in the job world on the same page.

  • Employers are frustrated because they can't find people with the right skills.
  • Employees and jobseekers are frustrated because they can't find good jobs.
  • No More Bad Advice author, Joan Graci is frustrated because of the growing divide between these parties.

 

No More Bad Advice is a book publishing & marketing campaign looking to shake things up & improve the lives of jobseekers everywhere!

Sick and tired of looking for a job in the same old way? Our innovative approach is drawn straight from the minds of hiring employers and has been proven to put thousands of people back to work in jobs they love.  

 

Isn't it about time we started working together on a solution? 

Help us to raise marketing money to spread the new employment truths through our book, No More Bad Advice. 

a)Please donate and say you've saved a career today (it could be yours.)Your donation will go to saving the:

  • The return to home grads who are desperate to move out of their parents house (permanently- guess what, your parents wish that too). 
  • The long term unemployed who followed all the rules and still ended up getting kicked out of the game. 
  • The back-to-workforce parents who are afraid that they've lost touch amidst the diapers and soccer games. 
  • The hiring manager who hasn't looked for a job in 20 years- have you thought about what it might be like to trade places with someone looking for a job? 

b)Join the cause for career happiness via Facebook or LinkedIn

c)For more information on Joan, Career Reform & No More Bad Advice, check us out on: 

www.nomorebadadvice.com

www.careerreform.com 

 

A Little About The Book & Author

As the owner of a successful employment agency and career coaching company, No More Bad Advice author Joan Graci is no stranger to the challenges of the new career frontier. For the last 28 years, she has made it her business to research, interview, and analyze the new dynamics occurring between employers and employees. What are the results of her latest findings?

 

Ask Joan a Career Question Here!

story:
For those who don't know me, my name is Dustin.

Beginning August 4th, I will be headed to Antigua, Guatemala for a month to volunteer in an after school program in a poor rural town outside of Antigua.  While I'm there, I hope to make a small contribution to the lives of these children by giving them a basic introduction to photography, sharing my passion for the medium, and encouraging their individual creative expression. With your help, I plan to supply approximately 20 to 30 children between the ages of 8-14 with cameras, and allow each child the means to edit their photos and make prints to keep for themselves. 

Where Does the Money Go? :

60 disposable Fuji film cameras - $300

Film processing & printing (approx. $15 per camera) - $900

The budget breakdown is very simple. I've already purchased 60 disposable cameras, which I'll be taking with me to Guatemala. Regardless if I come up short of my fundraising goal, I'm going to make this happen, even if I have to throw it on my credit card. I am by no means a wealthy person, which is why I'm asking for your help.

No, your money will not go my airfare or program expenses for the volunteership. It's all going to the kids. 

Unfortunately, the program sponsor, Maximo Nivel, does not presently have the means finance this project. Their humanitarian budget for the month of August has already been allocated to specific projects, mostly involving the purchase of medical supplies and educational materials. 

Project Goals

The main thing I want to do is simply to inspire these kids in a fun and creative way. I remember very well the first camera I had when I was about 12, and how excited I was to see the images I was able to create. Those experiences left an indelible impression on me. I hope to impart the same feelings of excitement and accomplishment onto these children. 

If all goes well, and this project is a success, who knows what may happen. There are many organizations that use photography as a means to empower disadvantaged children that have been very successful (ie: www.kids-with-cameras.org). I would love to see that photography continues to be a part of these kids lives well after I'm gone. 

If you're interested in this project, please stay in touch with me. If possible, I plan to regularly post updates showcasing the children's photographs.

THANKS!!

Dustin Wade

story:
I am currently studying anthropology and hope to eventually go for my Masters or PhD. I have a really amazing opportunity to take a 3 week study abroad trip around the area of Mexico City to study Mesoamerican archaeology in places like Teotihuacan and Oaxaca. 


This trip has come at a great time for me...it is a relatively short program for which I have saved up enough vacation time at work and will be a great close-up experience of the work archeologists and anthropologists do.

The total cost of the trip before meals and personal expenses is $3750, the majority of which I have saved up myself. Only this last bit remains.

All of my trip expenses must be in by April 1st and my deadline is closing in quickly. If you can't contribute, please don't feel bad! You cared enough to read my page. Feel free to share if you feel inclined!


Please visit www.austincc.edu/intstudy to see more trip details.

story:
Thanks for Helping Us Exceed Our Goal! Help Us Make PIKSI Do Even More.

Thanks to everyone who helped us meet our initial goal of $13,752!  You’ve helped us show how broad the professional support is for diversifying the face of philosophy. 

But we can still use your help! Our initial goal covered only one small piece of the PIKSI operating budget. $3,000 more would cover the costs of the visiting speakers who meet with and mentor the students.

If you’ve already donated, THANK YOU. Please help us continue spreading the word about this campaign.

If you haven’t given yet, please consider donating just $5 to further our goal and show how many of us are committed to changing the face of philosophy.

What is PIKSI? 

For nine years, PIKSI, or the Philosophy in an Inclusive Key Summer Institute, has been helping students from underrepresented groups develop the skills, confidence, and community needed to pursue graduate study in philosophy. Our students include women, people of color, LGBT individuals, individuals with disabilities, and people from economically disadvantaged communities. 

PIKSI aims to change philosophy's status as the least diverse in the humanities. Only 16% of full-time academic philosophers are women. Of the 13,000 professional philosophers in the United States, only 156 are black. The experiences of members of diverse groups can cast new light on traditional philosophical questions as well as raise new ones.

PIKSI selects talented undergraduate students from underrepresented groups out of a pool of applicants who compete to participate in a rigorous eight day summer institute. They learn about graduate school and experience a stimulating and supportive environment in which they can see how their interests and background can make a distinctive contribution to the discipline.

PIKSI alumni have already begun transforming the discipline. They have moved on to various successful endeavors, including graduate studies in philosophy at the masters and doctoral level, and even tenure-track professorships. 

Why PIKSI Needs Your Help

PIKSI has traditionally received two sources of funding. The program is housed at the Pennsylvania State University’s Rock Ethics Institute, who together with Pennsylvania State University School of Liberal Arts, have pledged to continue their partial financing of PIKSI, conditional upon funding from a partner organization. Until recently the American Philosophical Association (APA) has co-funded PIKSI, but beginning 2014, this is no longer funding we can count on.

We need your help to keep this important and innovative program going! 

What Impact You Can Make

Every year 12 undergraduate students are selected from a competitive field of applicants. We need to raise $13,752 to provide these students with:

  • transportation to and from the institute;
  • room and board;
  • meals;
  • books and materials required for the institute; and
  • a small stipend.

In additional to these, PIKSI incurs other operational costs relating to:

  • personnel, including PIKSI director and administrative support;
  • honoraria, transportation, and lodging for guest speakers; and
  • food and reception.

Graduate Assistants are generously supported by their home university departments.

In 2013, the APA's financial support of $21,000 went a long way to help with these costs. 

Make sure to check out the video the Rock Ethics Institute made about the story of PIKSI below, follow us on twitter, and friend us on Facebook to help get the word out!

This year, we need your help to keep PIKSI going and help change the face of philosophy.

For nine years, PIKSI,
or the Philosophy in an Inclusive Key Summer Institute, has been helping students from underrepresented groups develop the skills, confidence, and community needed to pursue graduate study in philosophy. Our students include women, people of color, LGBT individuals, individuals with disabilities, and people from economically disadvantaged communities. PIKSI aims to change philosophy's status as the least diverse in the humanities. Only 16% of full-time academic philosophers are women. Of the 13,000 professional philosophers in the United States, only 156 are black. The experiences of members of diverse groups can cast new light on traditional philosophical questions as well as raise new ones.PIKSI selects talented undergraduate students from underrepresented groups out of a pool of applicants who compete to participate in a rigorous eight day summer institute. They learn about graduate school and experience a stimulating and supportive
environment in which they can see how their interests and background
can make a distinctive contribution to the discipline. 

PIKSI alumni have already begun transforming the discipline. They have moved on to various successful endeavors, including graduate studies in philosophy at the masters and doctoral level, and even tenure-track professorships. Why PIKSI Needs Your Help
PIKSI
has traditionally received two sources of funding. The program is
housed at the Pennsylvania State University’s Rock Ethics
Institute, who together with Pennsylvania State University School of
Liberal Arts, have pledged to continue their partial financing of
PIKSI, conditional upon funding from a partner organization. Until
recently the American Philosophical Association (APA) has co-funded
PIKSI, but beginning 2014, this is no longer funding we can count on.

We need your help to keep this important and innovative program going! What Impact You Can Make

Every year 12
undergraduate students are selected from a competitive field of
applicants. We need to raise $13,752 to provide these students with:


transportation to
	and from
	the
	institute;


room
	and board;


meals;


books
	and materials required for the institute; and


a
	small stipend.




In
additional to these, PIKSI incurs other operational costs relating
to:


personnel,
	including PIKSI director and administrative support;


honoraria,
	transportation, and lodging for guest speakers; and


food
	and reception.


Graduate
Assistants are generously supported by their home university
departments.


In
2013, the APA's financial support of $21,000 went a long way to help
with these costs. 
Make sure to check out the video the Rock Ethics Institute made about the story of PIKSI below, follow us on twitter, and friend us on Facebook to help get the word out!
This year, we need your help to keep PIKSI going and help change the face of philosophy.

story:
Short Summary

I am not an economist or an academic. I am, however an individual with an active mind, good comprehension, with the ability to synthesize information readily. I am also unemployed and in debt, as is much of the population. I have turned my attention to economics recently. A good synthesis of the problem I believe we are facing with can be found in Working Paper No. 708, The Road to Debt Deflation, Debt Peonage, and Neofeudalism found at http://www.levyinstitute.org/pubs/wp_708.pdf. 

This paper posits that an inegalitarian concentration of wealth such as it posits is occurring today might actually not be a good thing for the majority interest, especially the high percentage of the population with little or negative net wealth and a steadily increasing debt load. I would like spend a year to read up on the available literature and reports on the subject, to prepare a synthesis of my findings, and to start a conversation on and promulgate possible solutions.   

What I Need & What You Get

I would like to be able to be able to devote my full attention on the problem for the period of a full year. As such, what I am seeking amounts to living expenses for a year in order in order to devote my full attention to this problem. I am not intending to live an extravagant lifestyle, however some of what I am asking for may also be used for travel to possibly meet with others trying to think along similar lines.

I am growing my reading list. I have just read Capital in the 21st Century by Thomas Piketty. The next book on my list is Debt, The First 5000 Years, by David Graeber. As my reading list grows, I imagine that part of what I am asking for may go to additional books or journals, depending on what is or isn't available from public libraries or the internet.

As for what you get, it partially depends on how successful I am in promulgating successful solutions to our (all of our) debt problems. I do not intend to subject my synthesis to the de regueur of academic submission, but I do intend to publish it to the internet, perhaps even paper.   

The Impact

If my ideas actually are successfully adapted and are effective, in particular ideas for widespread debt relief, I imagine that real economic growth free from debt overburden might actually be a rising sea that lifts all boats.

Risks & Challenges

Some of the ideas, economic theories and solutions I believe in are controversial. Some go against deeply ingrained, widespread economic beliefs. Some people may believe that their own interests are advanced by the development of debt peonage and my actively oppose me. My ideas may not spur conversation, may not take root, may never make it to the national discussion, or may be ridiculed. Alternately, my ideas may be adopted and may prove ineffectual or worse.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Join the Debt Collective, a group dedicated to finding a solution to our debt problems. https://debtcollective.org/ and on facebook.

Follow my blog for the occasional thought and some evolving polemic at https://apparentlyapseudonym.wordpress.com

story:
Short Summary

 Guinea-Bissau is the tenth poorest country in the world, much poorer than Haiti

Over the last seven years, IPHD (International Partnership for Human Development) fed up to 150,000 kindergarten and elementary school children in Guinea-Bissau, providing them with a daily lunch prepared from U.S. donated rice, potato flakes, beans, vegetable oil, and with locally purchased vegetables.  A few months ago, the U.S. Government’s Department of Agriculture ended the program.  This year, these children will not have any food in their schools.  The school lunch was the main daily meal for many of the children.  Many suffer from anemia, lack of Vitamin A, among other nutrients; many are stunted in growth, so that one commonly sees 8 year-olds who look like 4-5 year-olds.  Children suffer from parasites, and most come down with malaria at least once a year if not more.  IPHD also built and repaired kitchens in the schools, furnished them with pots and pans, installed water and latrines in the schools, and taught the children the need for hygiene.  IPHD developed the country’s first PTA system which now has over 15,000 members.  School enrolment increased and dropouts fell from 25-27 percent annually to under 2 percent.  Children were eager to attend school because of the school lunch as their families had little food available.  Now, that  the U.S. Government has ended the school lunch program, and the local government is too poor to purchase food for them, with most people earning only $1.00 per day or less, the children we help are sad, many are crying.  Families ask us  “when will school lunches return”.  We can only say “perhaps in the near future”.  Do we Americans want these children to be hungry, watch their health deteriorate, or stay at home rather than attend school?  The under 5 mortality rate is now 129 deaths per 1,000 children.  It was much higher before we began our program.  Certainly, it will increase for not only children under 5 years of age, but also for those up to 12 years of age.

What We Need & What You Get

Your contribution of $25.00 will enable a school child to have a school lunch for one month. $600 will purchase one ton of rice locally, beans are more expensive almost double that cost per ton. Individuals or groups contributing $600 or more will receive a photo book of IPHD’s school feeding program in Guinea-Bissau.

IPHD's goal is to raise $100,000 in order to buy locally at least 165 tons of rice and beans to feed at least 50,000 children of the 150,000 we would normally feed. The poorer schools would be selected for this assistance.

All donations are tax free under IRS Code 501(c)(3). We will send you an acknowledgement for tax purposes.

story:
I'm Chloe Lewis and I am raising money to offset what is not covered by my scholarships and financial aid to attend Maryland Institute College of Art.  MICA was one of my "Pie in the Sky" schools when I was applying to colleges this past spring and getting accepted was a real honor as was getting a Presidential Scholorship!  I am beyond thrilled!  But Top Ten schools are very expensive.  Even with my scholarships and aid package, I will have to borrow money to attend.  I am trying to raise enough money with this campaign to keep borrowing to a minimum.

My dad has always taught me that you can learn techniques but you can't learn talent.  You are either born with it or not.  I guess I was fortunate to be born an artist.  I want to study art at a top school in order to develop that talent to the best of my abilities.  I want to learn new techniques and ways of making art.  MICA is known for turning out top professionals in all areas of the art world and I plan to be one of them.  One of the things that impressed me most about MICA when I visited the campus was the emphasis on "hand making" as well as "digital making".  They teach time honored "old fashioned" ways of making art in contrast to the latest new media trends.  I am ready, willing and able.

Every contribution, no matter how small, will be money I don't have to borrow.  

A Short Biography 

My parents said I was always a quiet baby, as if not to make myself a bother. I’m still a quiet person, though I feel I have found my voice in art. Since drawing on the walls of my family’s home from the age of 2, I have been compelled to make my mark. Though I was typically punished for this activity, eventually it was recognized as talent rather then vandalism. I attended a four year fine art high school where I developed my technical ability of drawing, painting, ceramics, photography, and computer graphics. 

I want to invest more time in the ability to distort the human figure in various media. My long range goal of becoming a toy designer would be enhanced by mastering this skill as characters and figures are articulated variations on that form. I believe that illustration skills will enhance any area of design and art making, so that will be my major focus. Computer graphics are a major part of the commercial design fields and I look to master those in combination with drawing, painting and 3D imaging. I love letters and want to learn more about Typography. Designing my own font is a fantasy of mine. I also have a fascination with colors and how they make people feel. 

My career goals are to design toys children want to play with and adults want to collect for their aesthetics and design appeal. I really admire the sculpture of the artist KAWS as well as the KidRobot toy lines and would aspire to do something with that level of impact. Until that time I plan to continue learning by working in the design field under artists I can’t yet name but who do work I admire. The most exciting thing about being an artist is that learning is never complete. I love the process of becoming. 

The Campaign Goals

The money I am trying to raise will go toward fees and books that are not covered by my scholarships and financial aid package:

Student Life Fee ($480 per semester)  $960

Technology Fee ($290 per semester)  $580

Health Insurance Fee  annual   $1618

Total Fees not covered $3158

The rest of the $5K goal will go toward books, art supplies and plane fare to come home for Christmas break and Spring Holidays.  I will be spending Thanksgiving holiday at school as it is not practical to go home and come back with only a month left before the Christmas break. 

Other Funding 

I was able to purchase the MacBook Pro computer that I will need for my Graphic Design courses with my graduation money and the software I need is covered in the Technology Fee, so thank you to all who gave me graduation money.  You have already helped me toward reaching my goals. 

My Dad has already paid $1,000 deposit to reserve my place in the Freshman class and the deposit for my dorm and my meal plan.  Thanks Dad!

I am working with the Financial Aid Department at MICA to obtain part-time work at the school to earn some additional spending to put towards miscellaneous expenses and gain valuable work experience as I pursue my goals.  

Every dollar I raise via this campaign is money I will not have to borrow.  I am committed to this and will do whatever it takes, but I would like to graduate in four years with as little debt as possible.  Any and all contributions will be appreciated.  

How to Contribute

The way this works is you get perks for contributing to the campaign.  You can donate any amount and you select the perk for the correct level.  You can pay by credit card or PayPal and all payments are processed by IndieGoGo.  It is very simple and totally safe.  

If you can't donate now, I certainly understand.  You can still help me by sharing this campaign and helping me get the word out.  Use the IndieGoGo share tools to share this via Facebook and other social media.  Thank You!

And that's all there is to it.

expenses and gain valuable work experience as I pursue my goals.  Every dollar I raise via this campaign is money I will not have to borrow.  I am committed to this and will do whatever it takes, but campaign.  You can donate any amount and you select the perk for the correct level.  You can pay by credit card or PayPal and all payments are processed by IndieGoGo.  It is very simple and totally safe.  If you can't donate now, I certainly understand.  You can still help me by sharing this campaign and helping me get the word out.  Use the IndieGoGo share tools to share this via Facebook and other social media.  Thank You!And that's all there is to it.

story:
Our Story

The Human Experience (THE) was born from a very real need.  For the past two years, we taught the same group of fourth and fifth graders at a neighborhood K-5 public charter school near downtown Orlando.  During this time, we became more than students and teachers-we became a family.

However, as the end of the school year drew closer, it became clear that our kids were afraid to move on to middle school.  In fact, many parents were even afraid to send them.  Why?  Our students were zoned for failing schools with widely known bad reputations.  

These weren't just any kids, these were OUR kids.  We knew their talents.  We knew their dreams.  We knew their potential.  And we knew we had to do something.

So we created a school: The Human Experience.  A private, extended day, extended year middle school in the heart of Orlando.

The Human Experience, however, is so much more than a school.  It a space where students can learn, create, and dream in a family context.  It is a vehicle by which we can explore the ways a school can impact a city, and not the other way around.  It is an exploration of the question, "What does it mean to be human?"  A question that, if studied nationwide, could change the way we do education forever.

THE Orlando is one of a kind school with amazingly gifted students.  And we need your help to build it.

What We Need & What You Get

The school budget for our first year is $385,000.  We have spent the summer designing the school and speaking to private and corporate donors, yet we still need a substantial amount of funding to open the school on time.  All initial funds raised on IndieGoGo will go toward school expenses, which include uniforms, computers, software, school supplies, meals, field trips, books, and library resources.

As part of our model, each parent is required to pay something towards his or her child's education.  We calculate each family's tuition fees using a sliding income scale.  These tuition fees, coupled with funds raised by private and corporate donors, will total $210,000 ($7000 x 30 students).  This means we need to raise an additional $175,000 in order to meet our school goals.

If we raise ___________________, your generous gifts will help us provide:

$25,000 - Classroom Furniture & Operational Expenses
$60,000 - Uniforms & Two Classroom Paraprofessionals
$84,000 - Part Time Office Manager, Educational Software, Teacher Computers, Teacher Cell Phones (teachers will be available for homework calls each night)
$99,000 - Smart Boards, Mac Pro with Creative Suite Software, Office Copy Machine
$125,000 - Office Manager (convert to full-time)
$155,000 - Student Computers, Software, and Student Collaboration Lab Furniture
$175,000 - Student Field Trips

In return for your financial support, we have created some great Perks for you, including monthly publications, interactive art, personalized songs, a custom Personal Playbook of your own, and much more!

    The Impact

    Your financial support will:

    • Empower Students.  Every day, our students will wake up, dress in professional attire, and join the hundreds of movers and shakers that converge on the downtown area.  Each student will become an advocate for his or her family, neighborhood, and community in a place where decisions are traditionally made for them.  They will be empowered, for the rest of their lives, by the knowledge that their voice and their presence carry weight, significance, and impact in the spaces around them. They will discover how they can uniquely add value to the city they call home.

    • Teach Students to Invest.  The Human Experience strives to not only serve the community, but to also invest in it. We have a shared vision for our city and believe we can contribute to its long-term health and success.  As a school we understand our role in the greater Orlando community, in both the downtown business district and our local neighborhoods.  Students will be encouraged to dream about the future of their city, create solutions to complex problems, and ultimately shape the culture in life-giving ways.  We desire to lay roots in our city’s rich soil, producing stability, protection, and fruit that will benefit its citizens for generations to come. 

    • Set a New Course.  Over the course of the school year all students will create a working "Personal Playbook," a detailed life plan designed to give each student a clear view of his or her talents, desires, and life goals.  This will enable students to view their education, their interests, and their passions in the context of their greater life story, changing their future career from an endpoint to a pathway to a healthy, meaningful life.  Our students will be empowered with a straight path from Point A to Point B and beyond. 

    • Posit a Powerful, Game-Changing Question.  "What does it mean to be human?" The Human Experience is a school designed to explore this question, its implications on the education of children, and its overall effect on our families, our communities, and our world.  THE sets itself apart with the belief that each child possesses an inherent right to dignity, respect, and honor, regardless of his or her academic performance, personal struggles, or disciplinary history. This core belief guides everything we do; from the way we structure our daily schedule to our dynamic classroom instruction.  It also affects the ways we interact with others in the community, especially those we perceive as being "different" from us.  We believe an individual's answer to this question reflects his or her beliefs about human life and indicates his or her ability to make competent decisions that value personhood.  

    • Widen Our Impact.  We believe in the spirit of cooperation.  We recognize that we are connected to the schools around us, whether public, private, or charter, and believe our actions as a school directly affect our brother and sister schools.  We view this as a great responsibility and desire to be an educational resource and source of inspiration for surrounding schools, teachers, and students.   Our model is unique, diverse, and broad in scope, and is designed to be implemented in any school across the country.  This means thousands upon thousands of children and young adults will have access to the practices, resources, and values that we use in our classrooms.

      Risks & Challenges

      The Human Experience was birthed from a pure desire to preserve and protect our school family.  However, it didn't take us long to understand the gravity of our decision to create a school.  There was no guarantee that our students would be able to follow us.  There was no guarantee that people would support us. There was no guarantee that we would have jobs.

      However, our parents and students believed and they stand with us today.  The people we have shared our story with believe.  And we continue to work hard, believing that we will be teaching our kids at the beginning of the school year.

      Like our students, the odds were stacked against us from the beginning, but time and time again doors have opened and the people have stepped up to support us. We are an underdog in this fight, but we are stubbornly committed to giving our kids the education and the experiences they deserve.  We are willing to work longer hours and more school days because we know these children on a deep level and we believe in them.

      We cannot overcome this challenge without you.  Please consider joining us on our journey to strengthen our little family and positively impact our city.  Thank you for believing in us.  We are so grateful for your support.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Even if you can't financially contribute, there are a variety of things you can do to help us on our journey:

      • Spread the Word.  If you believe in what we are doing, pass along our story!  IndieGoGo makes it easy to share our campaign through social media.  Over the course of the campaign we will be releasing a series of videos that you can share on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and Google Plus.
      • Tell an Educator.   Teachers stick together.  If you know someone who works in the field of education, let them know about what we are doing.  They know firsthand the challenges that our school will face in the year ahead.
      • Check Out Our Website.  Our website, theorlando.org, has a variety of resources including our mission, our backgrounds, and a donor prospectus.  There's more to the story.  Go check it out!
