I don't like asking for help without being able to help others in return so I am offering a special gift for each contribution. This is my way to thank you for your generosity. The gifts you receive are yours to keep or to give away to someone else. I love paying it forward. 
Here is what I am offering for each contribution:
*25. donation = Citrus Bliss Hand Lotion: Citrus Bliss Hand Lotion softens and hydrates skin and enlivens the senses with the delightful aroma of Citrus Bliss Invigorating Blend. The essential oils included in the lotion are: wild orange, lemon, grapefruit, mandarin, bergamot, tangerine, clementine and a hint of vanilla. Great relaxing blend! With benefits that extend beyond elevating mood and reducing stress, Citrus Bliss has natural, potent compounds with cleansing properties. Makes a great gift. Retail value $8.67.
*50. donation =Citrus Bliss Hand Lotion, Citrus Bliss Bath Bar, & Peppermint and Wild Orange Lip Balm. Enjoy a bottle of silky smooth citrus bliss hand lotion, a Citrus Bliss bath bar  with milled oats, and natural emollients from coconut, sunflower, safflower oil and shea butter. The bar is free from harsh, artificial fragrances and colors and other ingredients that can be irritating to the skin. You will also receive a yummy Lip Balm with shea butter, mango seed butter, and sweet almond oil infused with dōTERRA peppermint and wild orange essential oils. Makes a great gift for someone. Retail $24.32
*100. donation= Spa Hand and Body Lotion & one 15 ml. bottle of Lavender Essential Oil.  The Spa Hand and Body Lotion is fragrance free, light-weight, and is perfect for hydrating the skin and powerful when combined with an essential oil of your choice. Contains a perfect blend of antioxidants, botanicals, and humectants with cruciferous vegetables  to help build the skin's natural protection and environmental defenses. Lavender essential oil has been cherished for its unmistakable aroma and its therapeutic properties for thousands of years and is used for its calming and relaxing qualities. Use the lotion with a few drops of lavender oil on your hands and body for it's many relaxing and soothing properties. Retail value $47.33. 
*150 donation = Introduction to Essential Oils Kit, Spa Hand and Body Lotion, & Lip Balm. The Introduction to Essential Oils Kit includes an introductory audio CD and booklet and three 5 ml bottles of Lavender, Lemon, and Peppermint essential oils. The stunning presentation box also includes suggested uses of the included oils providing an immediate experience of the life-changing benefits of essential oils. Also included is the Spa Hand and Body Lotion.  This fragrance free, light-weight lotion is 
perfect for hydrating the skin and is even more powerful when combined 
with the essential oil or blend of your choice.  The way to silky, 
smooth skin lies in the perfect blend of antioxidants, botanicals, and 
important humectants.  Extracts of cruciferous vegetables contribute to 
the formula's ability to help build the skin's natural protection and 
environmental defenses. You will also receive a yummy lip balm with wild orange and peppermint essential oils. Retail value $52.33.
*200 donation= Spa Mist Vapor Diffuser and the yummy essential oils of Lavender and Wild Orange. SpaVapor  Advanced Wellness /The Spa Vapor Ultrasonic  Mister! 
  The ultrasonic technology creates an ultra fine mist. This diffuser is 
BPA free and offers a convenient on/off and led light switch on the 
front of the unit. The unit is easy to use and simple to clean. Just add
 a few drops of oil into your tap or bottled water (not distilled), and 
turn any room into a healing, relaxing oasis within seconds.  Enjoy the 
beautiful and tranquil led light display of 6 fading colors to further 
enhance your relaxation experience. You will also receive two 15 ml bottles of Lavender and Wild Orange essential oils.Cold-pressed from the orange peel, wild orange
 is excellent for energizing and revitalizing.  It is also commonly used
 as an effective tool for uplifting mood, as well as for its wonderful 
citrusy aroma.  For aromatic, topical, or dietary use. Makes a great gift. Retail value $104.00 
*350. donation= Lotus Diffuser, 15 ml bottle of Serenity Essential Oil, and $150. gift certificate for doula services OR 15 ml. bottle of Frankincense Essential Oil.  The Lotus diffuser The Lotus diffuser uses a highly efficient 
real time atomization technology to effectively diffuse essential oils 
into the environment. The essential oils are atomized into minute ion 
particles and active oxygen anions, which are more easily absorbed by 
the human body than oils diffused by conventional diffusers. This diffuser uses real time atomization technology to effectively diffuse essential oils into the environment. You will also receive a 15 ml. bottle of Serenity oil. Serenity is a blend composed of individual 
oils with known calming properties which create a sense of well-being 
and relaxation.  Lavender, sweet marjoram, roman chamomile, ylang ylang,
 sandalwood and vanilla bean all create a subtle aroma ideal for aromatic 
diffusion or topical application. You will also receive $150. gift certificate for birth doula services either for yourself or gifted to a friend. Must be for someone in the Phoenix area. If you do not have someone to gift the doula services to, you may choose a 15 ml. bottle of Frankincense instead. Perhaps the most precious of the ancient oils,
 frankincense is highly sought after by modern consumers for its many 
uses, including relaxation, immune support, and mood enhancement. For 
aromatic, topical or dietary use. Total retail value of diffuser, oils, and doula services $310. Total retail value for oils and diffuser $243.
*500. donation= Family Physician Kit, 5 ml bottle of Helichrysum, and $200. gift certificate for doula services.  The Family Physician® Kit is a collection of 
ten nurturing essential oils, including six single oils and four blends.
  The stunning box includes tips for using the oils, as well as an audio
 CD teaching listeners how to care for 
their family's everyday health needs with simple and safe methods using 
the ten essential oils included in this kit.  Includes 5 ml bottles of 
Lavender, Lemon, Peppermint, Melaleuca, Oregano, Frankincense, Deep 
Blue®, Breathe, DigestZen®, and On Guard to help families address a 
multitude of health issues. One of the most sought-after essential oils,  helichrysum has traditionally been used for its soothing and 
regenerative effects. The rare essential oil of helichrysum is distilled
 from the flower cluster of an evergreen herb and is highly prized by 
essential oil users. I have used it for pain and healed a 3rd degree burn, preventing scarring.  For aromatic and topical use. Also, you will receive a $200. gift certificate toward labor doula services for home, birth center, or hospital. This can be gifted to someone else- and must take place in Phoenix, Arizona. Retail value for the kit, helichrysum, and doula services $466.67. 
Any contribution you can make would be appreciated and I hope that I will be able to gift you with something that you will enjoy! Use it for yourself or give it to someone else! Let's all help one another! 
*Finally, here's a break down of how your contributions will be used: 
*Midwifery Training Program- 1st Phase {one year}- $2500.
                                                      2nd Phase {Clinical Immersion}- 6-9 mos. $1750.
                                                      3rd Phase- Internship $TBD
*Neonatal Resuscitation Certification- $50-$240.
Breakdown: Book, Test, and Training
*CPR/First Aid Certification for Healthcare Professional- $100.
*Current Midwifery Apprenticeship - {Gas Mileage, Supplies, Childcare}- $2000.
*Midwifery Textbooks- $1600.
Total Breakdown:
Varney's Midwifery 5th edition- $153.
Anne Frye's Holistic Midwifery Vol 1 & 2- $199.50
Understanding Diagnostic Tools- $61.75
Anatomy & Physiology for Midwives- $34.
Midwifery: Best Practice- $42.
Optimal Care in Childbirth- $46.
Bates Guide to Physical Examination- $74.
Prof. Ethics in Midwifery Practice- $54.
Healing Passage- $140.
Birth Emergency Skills Training- $34.
Midwifery Mind and Spirit- $43.
Breastfeeding Answer Book- $45
The New Midwifery- $45
William's Obstetrics- $27
Bestfeeding: Getting Breastfeeding Right- $22
Practical Skills Guide for Midwifery- $80
Womanly Art of Breastfeeding- $13.
Human Labor & Birth- $80
Drugs in Pregnancy/Lactation- $44
Medication and Mother's Milk- $37
Neonatal Resuscitation Textbook 6th edition- $35
Assessment and Care of the Well Newborn- $45
Old's Maternal-Newborn Nursing &Women's health Across the Lifespan- $74
*Midwifery Tools/Equipment- $1500.
Tool Breakdown: 
otoscope- $27., gloves - $10, urine strips- $12, doppler - $800, Fetascope- $125, reflex hammer- $3., watch- $3, birth tub- $500, blood pressure cuff & stethoscope- $45, pen light- $5, birth bag- $50
*Advanced Midwifery Practicum at Maternidad la Luz - $4900.
Total Breakdown- $2400. for the tuition & $2500 room, board, food
*NARM Study Retreat {one week before the exam}- $1000.
*NARM Exam to become a Certified Professional Midwife- {required for licensure to practice midwifery in the state of Arizona}
                                                     Application & Exam Fees- $2,000.
Estimated fees needed= $17,590. 
*If my funding goal of $1000. is not reached, a 9% fee will be charged by Indiegogo. The rest of the funds will then be used toward the above expenses. If my funding goal for midwifery school is reached or exceeded, only a 4% fee will be charged by Indiegogo and all the rest of the  funds will go toward the above expenses of almost $18,000. total. 
The more I am able to raise, the less fees I will be charged and more of the contributions will be used toward my schooling! So any amount no matter how small will benefit my education and I truly appreciate your contribution! 


The Impact of a midwife for every woman:

The United States spends about $98 billion dollars for hospitalization on pregnancy and childbirth and our maternal mortality rate has doubled in the past 25 years! This is despicable! The United States ranks 50th in maternal mortality - which means 49 other nations in the world do better at keeping mothers alive than the United States does! This can change! 
Recent research shows that midwifery care improves maternal health and mortality rates and birth outcomes. A recent article also shows that midwife-led births have better outcomes and women are more satisfied with their care. Click on the link and read what those women have to say about midwifery care! 
Giving birth is something that women will remember for the rest of their lives. Having given birth six times myself, I can remember each birth as if it were yesterday. I can hear the sounds of my babies crying for the first time, the smell of their newborn head the moment I first held them, and the warmth in my arms as they laid in my arms- their mouths open and searching for something to eat. I remember every smell and noise and specific words that were spoken. I remember how I felt as they each came into the world and sometimes if I smell or hear something similar it takes me back to their birth days. I tell them their stories and they love to hear how they were born. We will be telling our stories until we die. Twice I almost lost my life giving birth while I was under the care of an obstetrician. While I am grateful to utilize the surgical services of the obstetrical profession when they are necessary, the majority of women do not need a surgeon to give birth. The more midwives we have for women, the better our outcomes will be and the better chance women will have for a safer, more peaceful birth.
I want to be apart of that! I wholeheartedly support the idea that more midwives = better care for women and babies. Women are the ultimate decision makers. They need more midwives to choose from and we need to revolutionize maternity care in this country to improve maternal and child health.
I am grateful 
to be here to tell my story. I will continue to tell my stories, as we 
all do, until the day my time on this earth is over. It is who I am. It 
is who we all are. We are all our stories and experiences. We all have 
so much to share with one another. 
I hope you will choose to be apart of this too by helping me reach my goal of becoming a midwife. I am honored to serve women during this most memorable and important time in their life. It truly is a calling for me. With your help, I will be able to offer more choices for women in my own community. We can all do something to improve our world- just a little bit at a time- and in small ways. 


Other Ways You Can Help
Times are hard for everyone, which is why I am struggling to afford my education. I understand that you may want to contribute but for whatever reason are not able to. I understand and appreciate any help that you can give. If you can spread the word about my campaign and pass this on to others using the share tools, I would greatly appreciate it! Thank you so much and have a great day!

story:
Short Summary

    My name is Sam Saunders, and I am a student at the University of Michigan School of Music double majoring in music composition and piano performance. I am the founder and president of the community service group "Seventh Mile Music".    

   Seventh Mile Music is a group that provides free music lessons to youth in inner city areas of Detroit. Drawing from the abundant musical talent found within the student body of the University of Michigan, we arrange weekly trips to several community centers to provide lessons to children that are interested. As the group grows, we plan to expand and teach more students throughout the city. Through fundraising, we seek to be able to provide permanent instruments to the community centers and those that are particularly interested.

     Besides the many individual benefits that playing an instrument allows, playing music can bring people together. We have students play music with each other, and aspire towards group concerts for them to showcase all that they have learned.

      I worked on a program similar to this in a poverty-stricken area of my home state of West Virginia, and we held an end of the year concert. We had pianists, drummers, rappers, violinists, bands -family and friends came to watch and it was a great experience for everyone involved. Many of the kids developed a love for music and dedicated time to practicing that would otherwise have been wasted or spent getting into trouble.

      I believe that this program could be of great benefit to kids in Detroit. Drawing from the school of music and from the general student body, I hope that this group can grow and reach out to many areas of Detroit.

What We Need

     We are hoping to raise $2500 for our group. 100% of this money would go to buying instruments to provide for the kids to practice on. We bring our instruments with us to teach the children, but their musical benefits are hindered by the lack of instruments to practice on when we are not there.

The Impact

     Growing up in a family of legal aid lawyers, I have been exposed and taught about poverty and crime in urban cities for much of my life. I have learned that one of the greatest problems that kids growing up in an inner-city environment face is a simple one that is often overlooked -- probably because it is so hard to quantitatively measure. This problem is the lack of things for them to do. These kids in inner-city Detroit are stranded with few activities to pursue and little money to seek anything out. This is a serious contributing factor to teens getting involved with drugs and violence.
     One of the great things about music is that there is no end to it -- you can't one day be "finished" with the piano or violin. By getting the kids that we work with (mostly of elementary school age) interested in music, we can give them an endless outlet to fill their time, to express their emotions, and to get away from things -- as well as exposing them to the arts and potentially instilling them with a passion for music they would have never otherwise had the opportunity to find.
Other Ways You Can Help

     Since all of our money goes towards buying instruments, donation of any instrument would be wonderful and would be just as helpful as a cash donation.

story:
Short Summary

Tyrone Wilfred Tootoosis is the keeper of a rare and priceless Oral History Collection. In the1970's countless interviews were undertaken with Plains Cree, Woodland and Swampy Cree, Saulteaux and Dakota Elders, both men and women in an effort to document the histories of our peoples. Stories that are already only known by a few are recorded in this collection for the education of future generations. This entire collection is currently in a variety of formats such as reel to reel, DAT, cassette tape, VHS, and Beta. These will be digitized over time and will ultimately be available for educational purposes. 

Recently, this collection had to be moved from where it was being stored in protective cabinets. Sadly, the protective shelving was not owned by the collection's keeper and did not move with the collection. The collection is now being stored in boxes and protective shelves are needed for their orderly storage and protection.

What We Need

These shelves cost $500 each and we need five of them. The funds will be used exclusively for the purpose of buying shelves and fees associated with this form of fundraising. If we don't meet our target, enough to buy five shelves, we will buy as many shelves as we can with the funds that are raised. If funds are left over, that is not sufficient to buy a shelf it will be saved and combined with future fund raising efforts to obtain the number of shelves needed.

The Impact

Should you decide to help, you can forever feel a part of protecting these critical histories. As one Cree Elder stated in a 1970 interview:

"To those of you young people who in the future, will be listening to us in these recordings, listen carefully to the teachings, stories and songs...this is what we have to offer you, what we have left for you. By the time you listen to these recordings of Elders who have agreed to be interviewed, we will be no more and long gone. We ask that you take the information and knowledge that has been shared by our old people and translate and transcribe from our respective indigenous languages into English and take it into the schools. Only we have the responsibility and obligation to properly tell and share our history, our story."

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute at this time, you can pass the word.

  •  use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Lexie Mills wore many hats. 

He was a teacher, coach, drivers education instructor, not to mention a WWII veteran, husband, father, grandfather, and great community supporter.

Mr. Mills taught for over 40 years, in several different high schools.  Most of his time was teaching at Bloomington High School (now South).    He was loved by all, and always went the extra mile to help anyone in need.

We are starting this scholarship fund to carry on his legacy.  All funds raised will go to the Lexie Mills Memorial Scholarship Fund.

story:
What is Politicus?

Politicus is an advanced and innovative political simulation game. The player will take on the role of the head of government of a real-life country of their choice and has one term to make changes to almost every aspect of the country, such as health, education, economy, law and more. Every change has a certain impact on the state of the country as well as the player's support among numerous voter groups. The player will rely on the support of these voter groups to win elections and stay in power, which will allow him or her to fulfil their vision of a perfect society, be it a classless communist state or a libertarian paradise.  Our innovative voting system allows for an immersive and realistic simulation of the joys and annoyances of governance. The advanced economic system will ensure that the player's vision is grounded with financial constraints. Numerous other features, such as the existence of corruption make the game challenging and fun to play. Players must win support among many different voter groups, make political deals with their rivals, secure party funding and much, much more. The player will be able to change almost everything about their country through a number of ministries (hover over the icons on the right to see just some of the areas of government). Each ministry is responsible for a certain aspect of the country and will giver the player many possible solutions to very important matters, such as the foreign policy, welfare, health and much more.

The choices made by the players will follow them all the way to the ballot box, as each choice has certain political consequences. For example, improving public services will surely be welcomed by the poor, socialists and a large part of the population, but the upper and middle class voters will be not be contempt with the increased tax burden. The player must balance between different voter groups and reach a consensus that most of the voters will accept in order to get reelected. Almost every choice the player makes has some sort of effect on the voters, the country or both. The advanced simulation system in Politicus aims to recreate the real-life effects of most decisions through the use of real data and statistics, making it the most advanced political simulation yet. By making the right choices for the people the player can improve their country and win the next election...or end up jobless. 

Apart from creating a very entertaining game we aim to create the realistic political simulator that could be applied throughout many many education institutions in the United Kingdom and the world.

What We Need 

Politicus was made by a small team of two people. All of the systems used in the game are already finished, as well as a sizeable chunk of software development. The funds that we gain through crowdfunding will be spend on an additional programmer and  better graphics. With these resources we will be able to complete the game in early 2017.

Why Politicus?

Politicus will be an enjoyable and rewarding experience for gamers, especially fans of simulation games, while still being an accurate political and economical model that can be used for educational purposes. We believe in creating a game that is not only accessible and fun to play, but will also educate players about the power of their political system, the diversity of views and methods of solving problems, as well as the essence of democracy. 

How can you help?

We will be eternally grateful if you could contribute, but if that is not possible then please spread the word about our game and campaign.

Thank you for your attention!

story:
We continue to raise funds

Our initial campaign period through Dec 31, 2017 has raised over $17,500 in funds. These will be used for the project for teacher training in rural areas this year. These funds will cover the cost of training nearly 1,000 teachers. Our overall target for the first phase of the English Literate India project is 10,000 teachers and we continue to raise funds for the project in 2018 through this campaign. If you like our project, do contribute!

Nearly 140 million students in India are enrolled in government schools. Out of these 82% cannot read simple English words. They only know their local language. Why is this a problem?

Higher and especially professional education in India is only offered in English. Almost no English is spoken in rural India. Without an environment or fluent teachers, learning a language is near-impossible. This has limited the participation of children from rural India in professional education and careers for generations. They are thus left without the means to aim for a better life. English is the key to opportunities in India and for rural kids these doors never open. In India, #EnglishOpensDoors 

LeapForWord is a registered non-profit organization working for 10+ years to enable equal access to higher education by teaching English in rural India. How are we able to teach a language where there is neither an environment nor teachers who speak English? We spent a good part of the last 10 years trying to figure that out! 

India has 29 states and 22 official languages. Indian languages have originated from Sanskrit - one of the most ancient languages in the world. That means all of these languages have similar grammar structures. LeapForWord's innovative solution works on this concept on common grammars. We teach English by translating between English and any Indian language with common grammar patterns using translation algorithms we have developed in-house.

Teachers cannot teach a language that is part of the curriculum but that they can barely speak. What if they could deliver English lessons through their local language? Our techniques do exactly that. We teach vocabulary as well as grammar by creating rules on how local language patterns map to English. Some of the peculiarities of the English language are also taught using rules e.g. why is 'C' pronounced differently in Cat v/s City. Most native speakers intuitively develop these rules. Our methods teach them explicitly.

Having worked in the field for over 10 years, we came to understand the real cause for children not being able to learn English in rural India is the absence of learning environment rather than better solutions in terms of training material or teachers. So we developed new solutions based on field experience to address the real problem. From our programs we see that delivers results!

See a short video of our methods used in the classrooms in rural India:

 

Several people who study education policy in India have observed that although free and public education is available across the country the quality of education in English and Math is very poor. We have chosen to tackle the problem of quality of English as this is not just a subject or language for children from India but the opportunity for a better life. Such large scale change takes decades to accomplish. However, we have set upon ourselves the challenge to accomplish this in our lifetime. Our near term target is training 100,000 teachers by 2019 (project 100Kby2019) who will be able to teach English to their students through our solution. We want to achieve an English Literate India.

We think this is possible because we have:

  • Identified the correct problem, i.e. environment rather than curriculum is keeping children from learning English effectively.
  • Created a novel solution to make English rule-based like Math. English is taught as sets of rules and translation techniques.
  • Designed methods that do not rely on English-proficient teachers, a rarity in rural India, to teach English.
  • Low cost which will make it possible to be adopted in rural regions.
  • Developed a sustainable model by working within the public school systems and making use of technology.

These factors we believe has helped us develop a solution that has the capability to enable children from all over rural India to learn English even in absence of English fluent teachers or environment. Our pilot, where we have trained 2000+ teachers (teaching over 20,000 students), has demonstrated our solution is working.

The Hindu, a leading national newspaper wrote about us in their article 'English For All '

 NDTV a national TV channel, featured a story on LeapForWord's founder Pranil Naik.

TimesNow a  national TV channel features us as part of their segment 'The Good Crusaders'

YourStory.com features us on their SocialStory segment

TheBetterIndia.com featured us for our positive impact!

An article about our organization in the BaySideJournal

Our goal is not simply teaching a language but eradicating the barriers to opportunities that English is creating in rural India. The rural regions where we work, are also the poorer regions and deserve solutions that they can afford. We are a non-profit and we offer our training as well as teaching material available at the lowest cost possible. We are, to the best of our knowledge, the cheapest classroom learning solution in India. 

In 2017, we have caught on with the digital wave! Smartphones have become readily available throughout all of India. EkStep, a free online learning platform, has partnered with us and all our content is available as an App on the platform. The EkStep team with its experience in rolling out technology at the national level will help LeapForWord scale nationally! (EkStep is an initiative by the team that rolled out the Aadhar card system nationally in India. Aadhar card is the equivalent of social security or tax card.)

If you would like to support our cause, please back us. Your contribution will be used for training teachers to teach English in rural India. The cost of training one teacher is $19. Your contribution will make a difference! 

To support us select the level of support from $15, $25, $50, $75, $125, $285 from the perks section (the column on the right hand side of this webpage). Perks are a way of thanking you for your support by a humble token of appreciation. Any contribution $285 and above qualifies for all perks. For each perk there is an option of choosing a digital version to reduce printing and shipping costs. You can also click the pink 'Back It' button at the top of the page to contribute a different amount. For those who contribute via the 'Back it' button we will contact you by email for your perk preference.

For donating in Indian Rupees, please email us at englishopensdoors@leapforword.org

Share our campaign page with your friends, they may want to support this project too!

We started LeapForWord with funds from personal savings. Over the last 10 years we have operated by raising funds from grants. Institutions funding non-profits are fewer and sometimes have long approval processes. 

As awareness about our organization grew, we came across many individuals who have loved this project and have wanted to support and contribute. We would love for people to participate in this project. This indeed is a way to democratically achieve social change!

We are running this campaign to gain the support of people who like us feel that talented children from rural India deserve the same opportunity to higher education as their talented urban peers. If you believe in our cause, show us your support!

Out goal is to train 100,000 teachers by Dec 2019. Between 2017 and 2019 our programs will move from the physical in-person training to more digital training and to reduce training costs and improve the reach to various regions of India. 

  • Phase I - Jul 2017 to Mar 2018 - 10,000 teachers, $19 per teacher : Total cost $190,000
  • Phase II - Apr 2018 to Dec 2019 - 90,000 teachers, $6 per teacher : Total cost $540,000

We have so far raised $62,000 through our institutional donors. 

Our goal for this campaign is to raise $50,000 or more to be used towards training 100,000 teachers by 2019.

We use funds for teacher training as follows:

If unexpected circumstances occur, we may at times make changes to the planned fund allocation. In this case, the details of actual fund utilization will be provided in the semi-annual progress report emailed to each donor.

An English Literate village:

Joyada, a village in Maharashtra where we have worked the longest, is being targeted as India's first English Literate village. Some results from Joyada:

  • 20 students  have successfully cleared entrance examinations to get admission semi-English schools. Earlier not even a single student had been successful as there is a 20 mark English section which was always the primary reason of failures.
  • Students from our very first children's batch completed high school  (Grade 10) in 2014-2015. Every single student from that batch opted for Science (which is taught in English). 
  • Rural youth reliant on farming teach our programs for additional income. This additional stable income has brought better lifestyles for 15 such families.

An interim report on Joyada can be found here.

An English Literate Taluka (County):

Maval, a taluka (county) in the district of Pune Maharashtra has been targeted as the first English Literate county. We have been working here since 2016. 

  • 225 teachers took up our concepts because they found them to be of high value. Our programs are voluntary and not mandatory.
  • Hearing about our results from Maval we were invited by the nearby taluka of Mulshi. We will complete training of teachers in Mulshi by November 2017. 

An one page summary report on Maval can be found here. Detailed report here.

Working with NGOs: 

We have also worked with some non government organizations (i.e. outside the public school system but serving poorer communities). One such project was with Nashik Ashram Schools from 2016-2017.

  • About 900 students were taught in these schools
  • All students in our programs from grade 4 to grade 8 did better than the national average on standard ASER tests

A one-page report on Nashik can be found here. Detailed report here.

For his innovative idea of teaching English through regional languages and enabling its large scale adoption uisng technology, LeapForWord founder Pranil Naik was awarded the prestigious  Ashoka Fellowship. The Ashoka organization recognizes changemakers from all over the world working to improve society.

Some testimonials from the field from our partners, supporters and teachers:

Check our image and video gallery for more pictures and videos from the field - including a video of our Word Power Championship - a spelling competition we where students from several villages participate!

We know that the road to such wide-scale change will not be smooth. Here are some challenges we foresee.

Digital training: Training teachers via the digital medium will need ways to overcome some digital inertia among this group. To achieve this in the early phase we will train teachers who are influencers and technology enthusiasts (relatively speaking!). We work on the principle of diffusion of innovation. For any change to be adopted it needs to cross the threshold of 16% adoption. In Phase I our aim is to cross this 16%. This will make disseminating teacher training easier in Phase II.

Traditional teaching philosophies: Our teaching methods are designed to teach English in non-native environments with very practical and easy to follow approaches. However, purists or proponents of other teaching methods sometimes do not agree and they are sometimes decision-makers at certain institutions. Here we will have to contend with bias - this takes time. To contend this we methodically record our assessments and keep updating our programs with learning from the field.

Other challenges: Even after they learn English, not every child will access higher education. For some other barriers will come forth. However, when we see children in our programs be the first English speakers in their family it fills them with such confidence they believe they can achieve anything. And we believe this confidence in itself will enrich their lives!

LeapForWord was started in 2006 by six classmates in an MBA program at Syndenham College in Mumbai who believed that the sole purpose of a higher education should not be a higher salary but to improve society. We realized that English would open opportunities for youth from Mumbai's underserved comunities and we started teaching children and youth from municipal schools and evening colleges after work hours. The first batch in 2006 comprised mainly of waiters from Udupi hotels in Mumbai. Our journey took us to some of the remote villages in the home state of Maharashtra where we realized that rural India was indeed missing out on the advancement happening in other parts of the country. One of the reasons this was happening was the bottleneck of English. Thus began the mission to teach English in environments where little to no English is spoken by anyone. Our methods are fine tuned by years of understanding the problems by hands-on work in the field. In the last couple of years we have worked on projects to make an entire village and an entire taluka (county) English literate so that our solution and model can scale. Recent improvements in infrastructure where a smartphone is pretty much available everywhere across India gave us the tools to achieve scale at state and national level. As with any start-up some of the original team discontinued the journey while some of us took up this cause as our full-time job. Today we are a team of 19 full-time and 2 part time employees. Team LeapForWord keeps going to work everyday with the goal of making an English Literate India a reality!   

Our teachers, students, supporters and contributors have over 10 years helped us reach where we can dream of an English Literate India. We cannot thank them enough!

We would like to acknowledge here the efforts of our campaign team in helping us launch and run this campaign on Indiegogo. Thank You!!

  • Thank you Prashant Raje, Nitya Vaidya, Delzin Choksey for your help with the Perks.
  • Thanks Utpal Aradhye, Kranti Ravikant and Vaibhav Babaji for video support.
  • Thanks Ariana Abadian-Heifetz and Aditya Vadgaonkar for guiding us through your own crowdfunding experiences
  • And lastly, thank you our team of promoters (Amit, Aniket, Astha, Deepak, Milind, Perin, Pratiksha, Rahul, Sameer, Subir, Yogesh) for spreading word about our campaign. 

100K by 2019 - LeapForWord's crowdfunding campaign

story:
Our Story

YMCA in North Macedonia, Who Are We?

At YMCA in N. Macedonia we are a small team of 3 experiential education specialists and 1 Peace Corps Volunteer who works closely with us, in the main office in Bitola. But that’s not all – with us are also 10 more mentors who support the clubs around the country and 35 more camper alumni and Peace Corps volunteers to secure each camp implementation during the summer. We work to develop our Youth Development Program GLOW-YMLP consisting of two premiere leadership summer camps and follow up camper alumni community service clubs in many cities around the country who continue implementing learned activities at the camp.

Why Empower Youth?

Unfortunately, many young people often don’t feel compelled to actively participate in their community. In fact, many initiatives focused on youth engagement such as volunteering projects, local community events, or local civic organizations often struggle to maintain and recruit participants.

What Are We Doing Differently?

Our approach starts by first identifying the most passionate service-minded youth from every community. The 2019 program had representation from 34 municipalities!

Starting in July, these select student leaders join us in Krushevo to learn about their unique leadership style and the fundamentals of project design and community service. In addition to the classroom lessons at camp, students are fully immersed in English language and build long-lasting relationships with other service-minded leaders from their community. After camp, its these relationships that keep our youth enthusiastically engaged in the GLOW-YMLP clubs.

What Exactly Are GLOW-YMLP Clubs?

The GLOW-YMLP clubs program is an initiative that started in 2015 to allow camper alumni to apply their leadership and service training within their own community. Each club has a dedicated mentor to provide coaching and leadership training to build upon lessons from the camp experience. In addition, each club has the opportunity to design and submit a project proposal to receive funding from YMCA to purchase the materials they need to implement their localized community service project. For more about this year service projects, see here.

What is Our Impact?

Last year alone, 16 different GLOW-YMLP clubs dedicated in sum 1000 hours to community service across 22 unique service projects. In collaboration with their dedicated mentors, our youth clubs completed needs assessments across their communities and designed projects focused on: special needs youth, environmentalism, food security, life skills education, and city beautification. Rather than wait for opportunities, our youth create their own opportunities, but they need your help and contributions to support their service!

How Can You Help?

This year, we initiated the crowdfunding campaign to sponsor materials and supplies for the Spring Service Projects. Previous service projects have used their grants to purchase: gardening equipment, paint, trash bags, gloves, construction materials, and office stationery among other items. Your donation now will ensure that the clubs program continues to thrive and grow! Let us know if you have a specific club you would like to support, and we’d be happy to direct your funds to that club!

How much we need?

For this crowdfunding campaign we have set goal of 6% [3.000 $USD] from our annual budget for the program. Campers support the program with contribution of 11%. For the rest of the budget we work on corporate fundraising by building relationships with corporate donors which are mainly national social responsible companies with vision to invest in the country youth leaders.

Interested in Learning More?

You can check out the clubs on social media to see what’s going on. If you want to see past projects they’ve done, see last years activities here, and some more from this year here.

DONATE TODAY

Every dollar helps! We are looking forward to your partnership in empowering the youth of Macedonia!

story:
Its a great day today as I have decided to be of service to others in need.  I aspire to do this daily with the launch of my non profit called strive 365. I want to better serve the homeless humans that are on the streets of Washington DC and surrounding areas. I also aspire to help the disadvantaged and underrepresented youth in the area. I will do this purchasing a mobile cargo/passenger van that will function as a clean and organized supply drop for homeless humans, this unit will also be able to transform and function as a moving classroom that travels around the city to deliver useful tips, stay in school efforts, financial fitness, health awareness, crime rate reduction, teen pregnancy and drug abuse awareness and prevention resources to struggling teens. If you have been moved by any of the aforementioned ideas please donate $10 or more to this new and powerful movement. My goal is $50k which will enable me to purchase the cargo/passenger van, a large storage unit and supplies for the people we will serve. Thee are 8 million people in the Washington DC metro region...we only need 5000 people giving $10 each to bring this awesome idea to life. Its not about color its about helping humans. In the times we are living in we cannot wait for others to do right...we must move things forward ourselves and help each other through giving and volunteering. Donate today and make a way for someone else that is less fortunate.  Thank you in advance. Click on the links in the video to donate now or use the link placed above or below this video to donate and get a friend or two to do the same.

 

See supply list below>>>

 

 

Homeless Humans Supply List: 

Sleeping Bags (Below Freezing Proof) 

Clothes

Heat Blankets

Hand Warmers 

Feet Warmers 

Sanitary Packs (Wipes, Deodorant, Toothpaste, Tooth Brushes, Lip Balm, Skin Protectant etc) 

Radio (hand crank ones that do no require batteries) 

Food (non perishable i.e. energy bars, juice, water and milk containers) 

$5 gift cards to area restaurants 

Info kits to local shelters, food banks and organizations 

 

Disadvantaged Youth Supply List: 

Books

Employment/Job Search Help

Food Programs  

College Preparedness Guide

Jeans (Jeans for Teens Program) 

Local Teen Enhancement Resource Guide

Useful Internet Research and Positive Information Links 

Stay In School Programs 

Safe Sex/No Sex Resources

Depression/Suicide Resources 

Drug Awareness/Drug Abuse Resources 

M.E.S.A Programs

story:
Give a closed school new life

Mangoplah is a small village located south of Wagga Wagga in NSW, Australia.

The school, which opened in the 1920s was closed by the Department of Education in 2012.  

The site is now for sale, and we want to buy it and turn it into community hub and sustainability education centre, offering learning opportunities for people of all ages.

We also have visions of developing a school inspired by Fitzroy Community School and Candlebark School (both located in Victoria).

The 10,000 square metre site currently has two buildings, a toilet block, sporting fields and lots of open space to create community gardens and an interactive outdoor learning space.

This project is an opportunity to breathe new life into an old school site, as well as contribute to the growth of a lovely country community.

Any funds we receive will be used to purchase the site, which is listed for sale at $AU 187,000, and get the learning centre up and running.

story:
Why create a Generation of Ocean Guardians?

The Mozambique coastline is home to some of the rarest and richest marine life in the World. It's one of the only places you can see whale sharks and manta rays all year round. This marine wildlife sanctuary is also unprotected.

Around 45 % of the local people in this area work in and around the water, yet the majority cannot swim. Each year thousands of people drown trying to provide food for their families. In the village of Tofu alone, up to four people per day can drown in the summer months, many of them children.

A lack of education and inherent fear of the ocean, means that most Mozambicans are unaware of the true value of their ocean and the critical threats it faces: 

  • Commercial fishing has reduced the amount of fish and hence food for local families 
  • The nets have destroyed the coral reef
  • Illegal poaching of rare species has drastically reduced their populations  
  • In the past decade there's been an 88% decline in manta rays and 80% decline in whale sharks ...and the list goes on...

The kids of Mozambique deserve a future and so does the Ocean !

Nemos Pequenos/Little Nemos (education division of the Marine Megafauna Foundation) is a swimming and marine conservation program based in Mozambique. 

  • We teach kids to SWIM today to stop the drownings
  • We ACT together to save precious marine life  
  • To PROTECT their ocean heritage for tomorrow 
  • We create OCEAN GUARDIANS

Now, we are asking you to dive in!

We are seeking $5000 in 30 days to ensure the long term viability of this program and its expansion across Mozambique. 

Can you dive in ? 

All proceeds raised will go immediately to employ the local instructors, and keep the kids in school!  

The Impact

We have been running this program with qualified local people for 2.5 years and here's what we've achieved:

  • We've taught over 200 children to swim and seen a dramatic decline in child fatalities in this area over this time
  • Developed partnerships with the local school, lodges and dive centre 
  • Provided EFR and SA 'Learn to Swim' certification for local instructors

With YOUR HELP we will survive and expand this important program across the whole of Mozambique and eventually the World!

Other Ways You Can Help

There are also other ways to support this Campaign:

  • Get word out and make some noise about creating Ocean Guardians in Mozambique 
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Kat and Tommy

This campaign is only being sent to a handful of people we love.  If you can sponsor Kat for even a day, we are grateful.  If you can't, please know that we are FILLED with love and support, and we are grateful to you ANYway. I'm giving classes on social media and branding as a thank you to anyone who wants them.  If you can't afford to support our quest, but need the class, just donate $1 and you'll get the videos.  :)  
  • Tommy starts chemo on 6/30 and it's going to be a rough summer.
  • Kat's already been through a lot for a young person... 
  • If I can get her out to something wonderful for a few weeks, I think it could save her spirit.

We need $2,000 for this amazing sleep away camp run by Omega Institute to get Kat out of the house at the worst point in Tommy's chemo 

Yes, it's not something I would normally do... but I am told that this camp is special... it's for misfit kids who need to find their stride... it called to us even BEFORE this happened to Tommy, but now we are caught needing all of our resources to get Tommy through the next few months...  so we're asking for help.  

  • The camp is $2,000 for two weeks - at the height of his first round of aggressive chemo.  
  • You can learn more about it and see what we love it for her here: http://vimeo.com/84245177 
  • Thank you either way, 100%.

If I raise any extra funding, I'll put it into whatever we do for Kat as this rolls forward.  We're headed into the toughest journey I can imagine for a family, and supporting Kat is the thing I can't quite wrap my head around....  so even if all you have to offer me is a powerful suggestion and an evening spent with her, I am here, I am grateful, and I will always, without question, support you too.  With LOVE and appreciation, mary agnes.

story:
Hello, my name is Diana Alejandra Rivera, I am eighteen years old and I live at El Porvenir, La Ceiba, Atlantida. I have one sister named Lauren Rivera, and my mother is named Ana Cardona. The problem I’m facing right now, which is financial, started in 2008 when my grandmother was shot in our house. My mom has always been a woman who likes to work and succeed in whatever she does. That year she decided to open her own business.

  We were having a great time for what I can tell. But everything changed when some men got into our house and stole our money and killed my grandmother. That morning literally everything went from good to bad, getting to a point that it affected my daily life. Last year I was a junior in High School and I started noticing that paying my school was turning into such a difficulty. It has reached the point that now I am afraid of not being able to finish my senior year at my school-La Ceiba Bilingual School, commonly known as LCBS.

  The purpose of me wanting to graduate from my school is because it gives you the opportunity to have a better job, a better life style and in few words- a better future. In Honduras, you scarcely have job opportunities and if you do so, those jobs are only available for the people who are best prepared. That is why I’m trying to graduate from LCBS, because they give me the opportunity to get a scholarship and study abroad for university. I have worked really hard to earn the position I have at school and it really hurts me to know that probably all the effort I have made so far, can just fade.

  I am concerned for what is happening because in Honduras we have an age limit to graduate from high schools, it is normally eighteen years old, maybe nineteen, which makes it even more difficult. However, I still have big plans for my future. I’ve decided that I want to study in the United States of America. Some colleges in the states are accredited to receive foreign students so, at my school, they can help us get in contact with the principal and try to apply to the universities over there. But I don’t want to stay there for my entire life, I want to come back to Honduras and offer people (having single women as my main objective) the opportunity to have a decent job. I love to volunteer. Since my mom started to get involved in tourism, community service and more, I have found my passion for helping others.

  I have been an interpreter and a teacher. I am a teacher at my church, Heaven’s Door and at Honduras Child Alliance (HCA). I think it is my duty to share with others the opportunity I’ve had so far of being a bilingual girl. Therefore, I value being an english teacher and sharing my knowledge with my community. Not every teen has the chance to be bilingual and I think my sister and I are blessed for knowing two languages already. It commonly happens here that teens think "this is it" - that there’s nothing beyond Honduras, that they don't have any options.  I know there is way more, and I’m willing to explore what is out there and provide my country the tools to become a better country. It might be one person at a time, but with knowledge and wisdom every dream can come true. Thank you for reading this brief story of my life. All of that is Diana.

~Diana Rivera

story:
Krista-Marie.  A happy beautiful child diagnosed within the Autism Spectrum.  

Short Summary

Hi everyone!

I am a strong mom that has been fighting with extreme obstacles in order to improve the life of my special need child, Krista-Marie.  I quickly learned how society operates.  How "Perfect you can be in an Inperfect World".  After twelve beautiful years of an extreme bond between me and my beautiful daughter, she passed away one night in her sleep.  Three months later, I received a death certificate stating Undetermined Death.  What the hell does that mean?  So many questions came to my mind?  Why?  She was not on any medication?  She was not sick?  She was happy and the most loving child I had ever know.  

What was the reason for this lesson?

Should her name just die like that? NO! 

I was exposed to such a different world.  A world of children struggling and in need of the right devices, therapies and assistance to bloom in this great world of ours.

For this I ask you to please help me help the children in need.  Be part of this wonderful campaign.  

Please donate and make a difference in a child's life today.  Thank you!

Marta 

What We Need!

We needs funds!  Lots of it!  Population is growing and too many children are lacking the proper therapy and assistance in order to reach their individual potentials.  The Krista-Marie Touch of Love Charity, Inc. is focused on our local schools Autism classroom's educational tools that will enhance a child's learning abilities.  Special need classrooms require aides that promote sensory, visual, physical, speech and occupational tools for a child with Autism and other related disorders.  For one child it might be as simple as a hearing aide, for another it might be speech therapy or learning to communicate with a device.  Your contribution will make a difference in the ability for a child to learn life skills, communicate their thoughts and teach us about the way they see life.

In her essence, may we not lose hope in others.

Krista-Marie lost her life unexpectedly, but her love towards people will continue in my persistence to help children in need.  This will not be easy, but she will be my light of strength!

Other Ways You Can Help

I truly understand if your heart is there, but you can't financially give funds.

Please circulate this campaign with your social media contacts and help me spread the assistance needed.

Please make a difference in a child's life today!

Thank you!

story:
I teach Computer Science at Riverside City College in Riverside, California.

I'm teaching a programming class, Introduction to Programming in C++ on, Tuesday and Thursday evenings.  I have a really great bunch of students. 
These are evening students who work a whole day, some of my students work at strenuous physical labor, and they find their way to class on Tuesday and Thursday evenings and spend three hours from 6:00 to 9:10PM trying to improve their lives, get degrees, advance their education, make better lives for themselves and their families.  It's really a very inspiring bunch of students.

My class is not an easy class.  I give them real world computer programming problems.  Debugging, working with students individually, is a big problem for me because I'm just one instructor.  I can easily spend 20 to 30 minutes working with just one student helping them to debug their program.

So, I put together this Indiegogo campaign.  I'm requesting a goal of $1,600.  That would be $100 a week, for 16 weeks.  It would enable me to pay a student lab aide, that is  a former student who's already been through the projects, essentially minimum wage.  It would be great help for me and a great help for my students.  So thanks for any support that you can provide us.

Disclaimer, this is an independent activity that I'm doing on my own and it's not connected in any way with Riverside City College.

So thanks for your help.

story:
Journalism student takes on British Columbia!

As a journalism student at Mount Royal University I have been given an incredible opportunity to move to Northern British Columbia for the summer so I can get some hands-on experience writing for newspapers in Smithers and Terrace!!

Writing has always been a passion of mine and I'm excited to put my skills to good use at the Interior News and the Terrace Standard. However, I do need some help as I am a poor university student trying to make ends meet!

I'm nervous about the move because this will be the first time that I've lived on my own in a place where I know absolutely no one. But, an opportunity like this can't be missed!

I'm creating this fundraiser to reach out to family and friends to kick up some start-up funds so that I can fully enjoy this work experience without having to worry about money. Any donation received, whether its $2 or $20, will be put towards putting a new roof over my head on my journey into the alpine towns!

I will be spending May and June in Smithers, and the remainder of the summer will be spent in beautiful Terrace. I am seeking $1000 that will help me set up in an apartment, or basement suite, or anything really!

My folks are supporting me on my journey by lending me a car which forces my mother to take public transportation! Calgary transportation is the worst, but my mom would rather help me pursue my dream!!

Will you be apart of my dream team and support me on my journey? Any donation would be greatly appreciated and one day when I'm a famous writer I will always remember the people who helped me get started!

If you choose to make a donation I will stay in touch during my time in B.C. I will regularly update you if you'd like, either by email or through blog postings.

Lots of Love
xoxox

Caitlin

story:
MISSION:
Striving to impact youth in the development of self-confidence, self-discipline, and dedication for the skills necessary to succeed in sports and in life. 

ABOUT BRIDGEPORT YOUTH LACROSSE:
The Bridgeport Youth Lacrosse Club, Inc. is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization with a our mission of Striving to impact youth in the development of self-confidence, self-discipline, and dedication for the skills necessary to succeed in sports and in life. The club supports boys and girls youth lacrosse in Bridgeport, CT. The club is a member of the Connecticut-New York Lacrosse Association (CONNY), the organizing body for youth lacrosse in Connecticut. The club introduced the game of lacrosse to Bridgeport at the youth level in 2005. BYL is also a member of US Lacrosse Emerging Groups Program.

POSITIVE  COACHING ALLIANCE
The Club follows the youth sports philosophy espoused by the Positive Coaching Alliance, a Stanford University-based organization that with a mission to "transform youth sports so sports can transform youth."

What We Need 

The organization targets youth are various age levels.  Our current need is to raise $2,000 for equipment, specifically helmets for the younger group of 8-11 years old.  

    The Impact

    To impact youth in the development of self-confidence, self-discipline, and dedication for the skills necessary to succeed in sports and in life.

      Risks & Challenges

      Keeping inner city youth off the streets and out from under the influence of negative examples in their neighborhoods by providing a positive, team activity with life-changing leadership and direction.

        Other Ways You Can Help

        If you can't contribute money, please use the Indiegogo share tools and other social media outlets to get the word out!

The club is a member of the Connecticut-New York Lacrosse Association (CONNY), the organizing body for youth lacrosse in Connecticut. The club introduced the game of lacrosse to Bridgeport at the youth level in 2005. BYL is also a member of US Lacrosse Emerging Groups Program.POSITIVE  COACHING ALLIANCEThe Club follows the youth sports philosophy espoused by the Positive Coaching Alliance, a Stanford University-based organization that with a mission to "transform youth sports so sports can transform youth." story:
What It Is

From youth programming to animal advocacy (and everything in between), Dave and I have always been passionate about humanitarian issues. After learning more about the Zambia Project, a student-driven organization at St. Norbert College providing hope through education for Zambia's most vulnerable children, we had a deep yearning to do more. 

Thus in May 2014, we will be traveling with a group of St. Norbert College students on a service trip to assist the Zambia Open Community Schools (ZOCS), which provides a basic education to children who would not otherwise receive the opportunity. 

We need your help to make this possible.

What We Need

Imagine a classroom without desks, learning without books, even homework without paper and pencils. This is the reality for many underprivileged children in Zambia. 

In addition to the cost of travel, lodging in youth hostels, meals and vaccinations, we would like to gift a significant amount to the consortium of 18 schools involved with the Zambia Open Community Schools initiative. This gift will make a significant impact in the lives of these very deserving children. 

We are striving to raise a total $4,000. PLEASE help us get there!

What We Hope

The Zambia Project was created in August of 2001 as a means of living the St. Norbert College mission of service to others. Since that time, countless students have participated in the Zambia Project to educate the campus community on issues of social justice in sub-Saharan Africa through fund-raising efforts to benefit the Zambia Open Community Schools (ZOCS). Without the ZOCS, many children whose families cannot afford government school fees would be left behind. As a community based project, ZOCS exists to enable some of Zambia's most needy children to access basic quality education.

Just think of the impact on a community whose children are given hope for a bright future through education.

How You Can Help

Gifts come in many forms, so we encourage you to be creative! 

In addition to a financial contribution, please:

  • Forward our email message to your family and friends!
  • Share our plan via Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter!
  • Follow our journey via the blog (to be established shortly)!

And that’s all there is to it. With gratitude for your support, THANK YOU!!!

story: My Name is Bimal Aryal from Nepal. I am a graduate student (MA in International Development Studies) in Saint Mary's University, Halifax, Canada starting from 3rd Sept 2014. I was born to a very poor family living in the hills of rural Nepal. I had to stop going to school at the age of 10 because my house along with other 14 houses in our village burned down. Fortunately, with the support of United Mission to Nepal, I was able to complete my high school studies. Due to my economic circumstances, there were gaps in my educational career, but I completed my Master’s degree in Environmental Science and Management from Nepal. Now I know that some of the reasons behind this disaster were the ignorance of the people and the changing climate. With that horrible memory always in my mind, I understand the importance of harmony between humans and nature and the need for sustainable development and peace. For these reasons I decided to study further and also obtained a place in the above mentioned university. I have received 7000 Canadian dollars as a scholarship from the University and I still need $ 7065 plus the air tickets. A further advantage is that one of my mentors, Richard James Hoyle, a retired Professor of Dalhousie University, whom I have known since I was 12 years old, lives in Halifax. He has generously offered accommodations while I am in Halifax. My research interests are climate change, natural resource management, development with sustainability, and renewable energy. My thesis is entitled Environmental management in an urban fringe, a case study in squatter settlement for adaptation to climate change. It examined environmental aspects of urban environmental management and adaptation to climate change. The study focused on one squatter settlement’s adaptation to climate change and proposes strategies for managing the environment there to make it better prepared and more responsive to climate change. Specifically, it addresses biodegradable solid waste management to generate bio-gas, carbon sequestration to reduce total carbon in the atmosphere and a control system for its frequent flooding. Moreover it provides knowledge to the settlement people that they can generate money by managing solid waste properly to produce bio-gas. The changing weather pattern really has an adverse impact on our lives. So the knowledge I would gain through study in Saint Mary's University would not only benefit me but even possibly my nation and its people. For example, four years ago, the people of my village asked for help. The previous year they could not grow rice well. I told them it was due to climate change. I then advised them to plant rice seedlings in two different plots at different times and transplant those seedlings according to the rainfall. I met the villagers after a year and they told me that they had adjusted to the changing climate and were very thankful for my help. My career goal is to work with the people here in Nepal, helping them find such solutions in this changing climate situation so they can sustain their lives in the most difficult situations they face. If I can raise about $ 10, 100 dollars, I will be able to continue this program, learn more and then take my new knowledge and skills to the people here in Nepal, who is living in real poverty. The proposed research and study in Canada will enable me gain sufficient knowledge and skills to better service my nation and people, and also enable me to connect Nepal with broader international community, through Canada. In this way I hope to benefit not only myself and my family, but those living in my village and someday all over Nepal. I hope who ever read my story will help me to help my nation and its people.

story:
Summary

People Against Rape Culture is a 501(c)3 licensed non-profit operating in Washington D.C. Founded by Christine Gordon in response to the aftermath of Steubenville, we are a small group of educators, sociologists, policy analysts and communications professionals working to change the conversation around rape and sexual assault using education, advocacy and collaboration.


Rape culture refers to the practices, beliefs, discourses and laws that trivialize, naturalize, and excuse rape. We recognize all around us signs and messages from our culture that rape and sexual assault are not important and that it is the responsibility of victims and survivors to prevent rape, and we couldn't disagree more.

Rape Culture is:

  • Universities having video evidence of rape, finding the perpetrators guilty, and punishing them by expelling them after they graduate

  • Police having video evidence of a rape and closing the investigation claiming there's not enough evidence

  • Women who serve in the US military being more likely to be raped by a fellow serviceman than to be killed by enemy fire, resulting in sexual trauma being the leading cause of PTSD in military women

  • The Air Force showing how seriously they take internal justice by creating the Sexual Assault Prevention and Response Program and having the appointed head get arrested for sexual battery himself

  • And more of the same over at the Army

  • A judge telling a 14-year old victim she dressed older than her age and had equal control over the situation as her 49-year old teacher who raped her, who was sentenced to 30 days in jail

  • A police officer leading a sexual assault prevention program and telling participants to avoid rape by not “dressing slutty”

  • Venerable newspapers standing behind opinion pieces that claim sexual assault confers special privileges, and that marriage is the key to avoiding rape

  • Consistency in framing and reporting of rape such that what is pictured is the man jumping out of the bushes, when in fact 2/3 of survivors know their rapist, and many are married to them

  • A comic who responds to a heckler with a racial slur and gets immediate reprimand and censure for hate speech versus a comic who suggests the humor in a heckler getting raped and in turn gets overwhelming support for his right to joke about rape

  • The fact that all this goes on and powerful legislators, media outlets and organizations rail against the depth and pervasiveness of rape and sexual assault

Rape culture is so ingrained and prevalent that many people refute it's existence and claim that rape happens because survivors ask for it by not adequately avoiding the inevitable. We disagree and think we can do better by our communities, and we think education is the place to start.

Rape culture can be identified and challenged by developing age-appropriate educational programs that teach kids, adolescents and adults about consent, communication, and respect.

While there are many amazing organizations devoted to preventing rape, very few exist to challenge the cultural foundations that make rape so prevalent and inadequately challenged. PARC is focused on teaching communities how to identify and challenge rape culture to better prevent and address rape and sexual assault, and we need your help to accomplish that.

What We Need

We are asking contributors to help us raise $3000 to help cover our start-up costs and launch our services. Costs such as:

  • Filing fees to cover the costs of getting us our incorporation and 501(c)3 licenses (our team of pro bono attorneys were amazing, and fronted the money to pay these fees, but we need to reimburse them for those costs)

  • Materials for customized age-appropriate educational programs

  • Administrative and promotional materials like business cards, brochures and other handouts to help raise awareness about PARC so we can reach more people

  • Shared office space for hosting meetings, interviews, and administrative services

  • Marketing and advertising costs

If we don't reach our goal, all is not lost! In fact, whatever we receive will go towards these fees, educational and promotional materials, marketing, and administrative resources. We're working with nothing but our own pockets right now, so any contribution will be crucially helpful and appreciated.

The Impact

Rape affects everyone, not just the offensive and purposely misleading trope of the intoxicated co-ed walking home on a dark street. It is a traumatizing assault that a woman is twice as likely to face than breast cancer. 1 in 33 men will be victims of rape in their lifetimes. Rape claims almost half of its victims before age 18. Thousands upon thousands of women, men, and children will be traumatically violated and then be exponentially more likely to suffer from repeated sexual assault, depression, substance abuse, and suicide, adding up to a vicious cycle of destruction. 

We can't underscore enough how damaging and far-reaching the effects of rape and sexual assault are on the ability and right of survivors to lead healthy functioning lives free of trauma as members of our communities. Supporting PARC will be supporting and meeting a desperate and critical need for an agent of positive and effective change in how we eradicate this epidemic of devastating violence to support the human right to life, liberty, and prosperity.

Risks and Challenges

Financial insolvency is our biggest threat. We are currently an all-volunteer organization, doing what we can out of pocket and by accessing free or low-cost resources, in the time we can dedicate apart from our 'day jobs'. We address this risk by keeping overhead costs low and developing multiple overlapping fundraising strategies, such as seeking grants, soliciting donors and developing crowd funding campaigns. Adequate funding will in turn provide for more resources, most notably our time and energy and that of future staff we can bring on.

We deeply appreciate anything you can give. Take a look at our perks to the right, but if you'd like to make your donation go even further feel free to waive the gift. Either way, thank you for your support.

Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate that you may want to support PARC but can't do so financially, and we still want your help! You can like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, Instagram and Tmblr and share our webpage with as many people as you can. You can engage with us in conversations about rape culture here, send us your #ineedPARCbecause testimonial selfie, and invite us to come into your schools, communities, and organizations to offer educational programs for all ages. Lastly, you can engage with what we are producing and the message we are spreading, and continue this conversation in your own lives with your friends and family. It's time to change the conversation around rape and sexual assault, and we can't do that amongst ourselves. So thank you for visiting our project, and please consider helping in any way you can. We are grateful and buoyed by the support of our communities!

Photo

Creative Commons from Epiphonication

Video Credits

Music: Dexter Brian - Time to Run ; Bleak House - Biology Slides 

Video:  Kerri Redding of Brown Girl Breathing Media, videography; Kylé Pienaar, editing
