story:
Short Summary

ETHOS ACADEMY EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Primary Founders: Dr. Courteny Gumora, Sage Moore, Lydia Ropp

Mission & Vision Overview

ETHOS Academy Charter School is a public school that will serve Ninth through Twelve grade students of the East Bay, Alameda County in the Oakland Unified School District, located in the thriving Downtown Oakland Community. Ethos educational model brings together Transformative (student’s meaning perspective’) and Constructivist (student’s existing knowledge developed by experience) Education rooted in Project Based Learning (a collaborative with community based organizations). Ethos uses multiple perspectives, and multiple modes of representation in teaching Common Core and Social Emotional Learning Standards. Ethos addresses systemic social, academic and financial strategies for developing a
workable and sustainable Transformative new public school for Oakland.

Ethos Academy design is driven by the belief that students learn most effectively when supports for social, emotional, and academic development are incorporated into the structure and design of the school environment. These intensive personalized relationships form a core for how every student is educated and supported through
self-selected tasks and self-directed projects. The structure is designed to support all students, inclusive of all learning styles with particular attention given to skill level challenges and formal and informal diagnoses.

Who Does Ethos Serve?

Ethos will serve families in the greater Oakland area and all students are welcome. Ethos school and campus systems are designed to support Individualized Education Plans (IEP) and Individualized Learning Plans (ILP) as best practices for all student academic matriculation. Students of informal and formal designated diagnoses (particularly students with the diagnoses of Autism Spectrum and related challenges) will have a viable alternative to traditional school structure, assuring consistent appropriate support:

•  Guided by curriculum standards student initiate subject area activities and tasks, generated as independent ideas

•  Student learning style Counter Story Telling (verbally and documented) are used with instructional detail in an organized, sequential manner

•  Project planning support to master time management and organizational collaboration necessary for completion

How Is Ethos Distinct?

“Each child is a unique person, with unique needs, and the purpose of the educational system of this state is to enable each child to develop all of his or her own potential.”—Ed Code 33080

Ethos Academy Charter School forwards the mission of the Oakland Unified School District by offering an academic model driven by the conviction that “Education has a two-fold function to perform in the life of man and in society: the one is utility and the other is culture. Education must enable a man to become more efficient, to achieve with increasing facility the legitimate goals of his life… We must remember that intelligence is not enough. Intelligence plus character--that is the goal of true education. The complete education gives one not only power of concentration, but worthy objectives upon which to concentrate. The broad education will, therefore, transmit to one not only the accumulated knowledge of the race but also the accumulated experience of social living (Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.).” Consistent with the California State Board of Education, Ethos Academy commitment is to ensure that all students will attain the highest level of 21st Century academic knowledge, applied learning and performance skills to ensure fulfilling personal lives and careers and contribute to civic and economic progress in our diverse and changing democratic society.

The mission of Ethos Academy is to prepare students to be self-aware, responsible, life-long learners, motivated to meet the challenges of a rapidly changing world.  We develop future leaders by expecting academic excellence, enhancing critical and creative thinking skills, cultivating curiosity, and fostering social and emotional development in a nurturing and caring community.  Our mission is supported by
five core values:

• Personal Discovery: of the basic structures in which each student gains awareness of what they know, how they think, and act in the world through in-depth self-inquiry for Personal Transformation.

• Community Shifts in Awareness: guides individual student Transformation to develop their understanding of the strengths and challenges within themselves and others to create a supportive, workable and sustainable learning community and school structure.

• Connectedness/ Community: builds partnership with peers as fellow students and adults as educators who are also students of the larger academic community, through reciprocal teaching and learning.

• Knowledge Constructivism: provides new opportunities for students from diverse and traditionally low performing backgrounds to contribute legitimate counter story and prior knowledge to supportive learning environment.

Ethos Academy educational vision is rooted in constructivist learning theory, informed by neuroscience research, and pedagogical best practices. Instruction at Ethos Academy is based on a dynamic inquiry-based approach to teaching and learning. Ethos stand is that Constructivist Learning and Teaching as an academic social construct develops strong student learning identity rooted in Transformative Research Design (Mertens, 2009):

• Underlying assumptions that rely on ethical stances of inclusion and challenge oppressive social structures.

• An entry process into the community that is designed to build trust and make goals and strategies transparent.

• Dissemination of findings in ways that encourage use of the results to enhance social justice and human rights.

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • $1000. California Charter School Association Fee
  • $1000. Back Office Consulting Co. Fee
  • $  500. Miscellaneous i.e. Non-Profit Filing/ Indiegogo Fee

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

Dr. Gumora is one of the three principal founders of Ethos Academy and is an active member of the Social Emotional Learning Initiative Collaborative with the Oakland Unified School District. As a new and progressive Charter with Oakland
Unified, Ethos Academy academics and community are aligned with the five SEL
competencies. Social Emotional Learning (SEL) is a process through which children and adults develop the fundamental skills for life effectiveness. These are the skills we all need to handle ourselves, our relationships and our work effectively and
ethically.  These competencies will to be taught and developed in our students and modeled by adults in classrooms, school and throughout our system. Social Emotional Learning is not separate from academic learning but, in fact, is critical to the transition to and effectiveness of developing the conditions to engaging instructional practices needed to teach academic content through the Common Core State Standards. 

The Five Social Emotional Learning Competencies:

Self Awareness (labeling one’s feelings; relating feelings and thoughts to behavior; accurate self-assessment of strengths/limitations; self-efficacy; optimism)
Self-Management (regulating one’s emotions; managing stress; self-control; self-motivation; setting and achieving goals)  
Social Awareness (perspective-taking; empathy; understanding the socio-historical
context of diversity; understanding social and ethical norms for behavior; recognizing family, school and community supports)
Relationship Skills (building relationships with diverse individuals/groups; communicating clearly; working cooperatively; resolving conflicts; seeking help)
Responsible Decision Making (considering the well-being of self and others;
basing decisions on safety, social and ethical considerations; making constructive, safe choices about self, relationships and school).

FOUNDERS BIOS ALPHATIZED::

Dr.Gilberto Ariaza graduated from the University of California at Berkeley, Social and Cultural Studies at the College of Education. From the year 2000 to the spring of 2007 he taught at the College of Education, of San Jose State University (SJSU). I am currently at CSU East Bay's College of Education & Allied Studies. He has taught
courses ranging from organizational theory, leadership, system analysis, school
design, research methods, curriculum planning, community involvement in schools, and advocacy primarily to professional educators concerned with PK-16 learning. His work experience includes extensive research, leadership coaching and program evaluation in the public school systems. I have centrally worked for non-governmental and higher learning institutions.

Dr. Catherine Brown directs Accessibility Services at California State University East Bay (CSUEB). Dr. Brown's research interests include individuals with disabilities, parent involvement, and multicultural issues in education.  At CSUEB she developed and coordinated the College Link Program for students on the autism spectrum. This program provides academic, social, career, and residential "coaching" support on campus to manage student's strengths and challenges.  She is also a Licensed Educational Psychologist and co-author of publications in the area of disabilities.

Sheri Carbonaro is in the process of completing a Doctorate in Educational Leadership for Social Justice. She graduated from California State University East Bay with a Master of Science in Educational Leadership with a concentration in Urban Teacher Leadership. Current credentials include Administrative Certificate and CLAD Teaching Credential and obtained a B.A. in Liberal Studies with a concentration in Sociology. Has been an educator at a Title I school for thirteen years as designee and a lead teacher. Currently teaches in Fremont Unified School District at a Title I school which has earned the National Blue Ribbon Award and the
California Distinguished School Award. She also holds an Administrative Degree
in Educational Leadership.

Dr. Jack Davis obtained his Ph.D. in School Psychology from U.C. Berkeley and did advanced training at U.C. Davis. He has worked in a variety of clinical and educational settings. He is currently a professor at CSU East Bay in their graduate program in Educational Psychology where he is also Chair, and he maintains a private practice specializing in learning and developmental disorders. Prior to this he directed the Raskob Institute, an evaluation and treatment clinic located on the campus of Holy Names College in Oakland.

Dr. Courteny Gumora obtained her Ed.D. in Educational Leadership and Social Justice from CSUEB, has MA in Special Education, completed all coursework for MA in Cultural Anthropology, is Certificated Specialist in Autism Spectrum Disorder and Deafblindness, currently a CA Credentialed Moderate to Severe Special Educator and Coordinating Teacher for the Asperger Inclusion Program at Skyline High School in OUSD as an advocate for Transformative Education through Constructivist Learning/ Teaching practices.

Dr. Vera Jacobson obtained her Ed.D. in Educational Leadership and Social Justice from California State University, East Bay, a Master of Arts in The Creative Arts with an emphasis in Arts Education from San Francisco State University, and a Bachelor of Arts in Theatre Arts, from California State University, Hayward. She has five teaching credentials and is a certified Soft Skills Trainer. Dr. Jacobson is the Director of a California Partnership Academy on the Peninsula.  She has presented at
state-wide conferences and recently shared her research at the American
Association of Anthropology in Chicago.  Vera Jacobson holds an Administrative Credential with Contra Costa Unified School District.

Dr. Dana Mitchell works with the Department of Rehabilitation and iscommitted working collaboratively with community partners and stakeholders she is committed to finding solutions to complex problems and developing system change. As a Transition Specialist for nine High Schools and the Community Immersion program with the Oakland Unified School District she provides students opportunities to pursue higher education and/or employment pursuits to maximize functional independence. She was a sole practitioner for many years providing psychotherapy and counseling within a variety of mental health and physical rehabilitation facilities, involving disability rights.

Corigan Malloy is pursuing her Doctorate in Educational Leadership.  has
been an educator for 22 years she is currently teaching elementary school in
West Oakland.  She has presented at workshops in the Oakland Unified School district, focusing on classroom management and Common Core Math.  She
also taught elementary, adult education and community college classes in New
York, Hawaii, Georgia.  She is a published author.  She is deeply committed to the ideal of socially just education.

Bryan Moore is currently in his seventh year as a supporting team member and instructional assistant in the Aspergers Inclusion Program at Skyline High School. He completed coursework for BS in psychology at Colorado State University. Seven years of experience working with child sex offenders and a one-to-one aid for children with autism. Advocate for joy, promoter of fun and enjoyable classroom environments for kids.

Ian Patton is an Intervention Specialist in the Asperger's Inclusion Program at Skyline High School.  He has 10 years of experience serving the educational and
social-emotional needs of at-risk youth and students on the Autism Spectrum.
Ian firmly believes in power of experiential and project based learning.

Michelle Remy is a parent, educator and writer living in Oakland. She has worked with children and youth as a mentor, coach, teacher, camp director and after school program director. She has been both a parent and teacher at a successful progressive, K-8 project-based charter school and currently works in a high school Aspergers' Inclusion Program providing behavioral and academic support.

Lydia Ropp has taught at Skyline High School for 7 years, teaching Art the private sector for 20. She is an active participant in the Education in the Digital Age/ Capstone project to teach Government through civic action. Has completed all course work for a Masters in Education Administration and completing research on restructuring school bureaucracy; radically restructure the organization of the learning
environment to raise the rigor and realism of educational experiences.

Heidi Neipris Wexler has a Masters Degree in Counseling Psychology from California Institute of Integral Studies. She has worked with youth and older adults across the life spectrum weaving writing, cooking, and creative arts along with a personal passion for optimal health into our program for the past seven years, while helping to raise two teenagers of her own.

Mark Greyland has synesthesia, his work is dedicated to the blending of sensory stimuli with music and animation and displayed at ComicCon 2013 and in local galleries. Mark is also an ISTQB Certified Software tester for companies Xerox and Intel. Network Administrator has made him deeply interested in digital technology in art and music and in the creative lives of children including Marks twin son who is on the Autism Spectrum. Mark is the author of Stringbreaker's notebook, a guitar technique manual and has for NZ Musician Magazine.

 

How Else We Can Use Your Help!

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

Social Emotional Learning is not separate from academic learning but, in fact, is critical to the transition to and effectiveness of developing the conditions to engaging instructional practices needed to teach academic content through the Common Core State Standards.  The Five Social Emotional Learning Competencies:Self Awareness (labeling one’s feelings; relating feelings and thoughts to behavior; accurate self-assessment of strengths/limitations; self-efficacy; optimism) Self-Management (regulating one’s emotions; managing stress; self-control; self-motivation; setting and achieving goals)  Social Awareness (perspective-taking; empathy; understanding the socio-historicalcontext of diversity; understanding social and ethical norms for behavior; recognizing family, school and community supports) Relationship Skills (building relationships with diverse individuals/groups; communicating clearly; working cooperatively; resolving conflicts; seeking help) Responsible Decision Making (considering the well-being of self and others;basing decisions on safety, social and ethical considerations; making constructive, safe choices about self, relationships and school).FOUNDERS BIOS ALPHATIZED::Dr.Gilberto Ariaza graduated from the University of California at Berkeley, Social and Cultural Studies at the College of Education. From the year 2000 to the spring of 2007 he taught at the College of Education, of San Jose State University (SJSU). I am currently at CSU East Bay's College of Education & Allied Studies. He has taughtcourses ranging from organizational theory, leadership, system analysis, schooldesign, research methods, curriculum planning, community involvement in schools, and advocacy primarily to professional educators concerned with PK-16 learning. His work experience includes extensive research, leadership coaching and program evaluation in the public school systems. I have centrally worked for non-governmental and higher learning institutions.Dr. Catherine Brown directs Accessibility Services at California State University East Bay (CSUEB). Dr. Brown's research interests include individuals with disabilities, parent involvement, and multicultural issues in education.  At CSUEB she developed and coordinated the College Link Program for students on the autism spectrum. This program provides academic, social, career, and residential "coaching" support on campus to manage student's strengths and challenges.  She is also a Licensed Educational Psychologist and co-author of publications in the area of disabilities.Sheri Carbonaro is in the process of completing a Doctorate in Educational Leadership for Social Justice. She graduated from California State University East Bay with a Master of Science in Educational Leadership with a concentration in Urban Teacher Leadership. Current credentials include Administrative Certificate and CLAD Teaching Credential and obtained a B.A. in Liberal Studies with a concentration in Sociology. Has been an educator at a Title I school for thirteen years as designee and a lead teacher. Currently teaches in Fremont Unified School District at a Title I school which has earned the National Blue Ribbon Award and theCalifornia Distinguished School Award. She also holds an Administrative Degreein Educational Leadership.Dr. Jack Davis obtained his Ph.D. in School Psychology from U.C. Berkeley and did advanced training at U.C. Davis. He has worked in a variety of clinical and educational settings. He is currently a professor at CSU East Bay in their graduate program in Educational Psychology where he is also Chair, and he maintains a private practice specializing in learning and developmental disorders. Prior to this he directed the Raskob Institute, an evaluation and treatment clinic located on the campus of Holy Names College in Oakland.Dr. Courteny Gumora obtained her Ed.D. in Educational Leadership and Social Justice from CSUEB, has MA in Special Education, completed all coursework for MA in Cultural Anthropology, is Certificated Specialist in Autism Spectrum Disorder and Deafblindness, currently a CA Credentialed Moderate to Severe Special Educator and Coordinating Teacher for the Asperger Inclusion Program at Skyline High School in OUSD as an advocate for Transformative Education through Constructivist Learning/ Teaching practices.Dr. Vera Jacobson obtained her Ed.D. in Educational Leadership and Social Justice from California State University, East Bay, a Master of Arts in The Creative Arts with an emphasis in Arts Education from San Francisco State University, and a Bachelor of Arts in Theatre Arts, from California State University, Hayward. She has five teaching credentials and is a certified Soft Skills Trainer. Dr. Jacobson is the Director of a California Partnership Academy on the Peninsula.  She has presented atstate-wide conferences and recently shared her research at the AmericanAssociation of Anthropology in Chicago.  Vera Jacobson holds an Administrative Credential with Contra Costa Unified School District.Dr. Dana Mitchell works with the Department of Rehabilitation and iscommitted working collaboratively with community partners and stakeholders she is committed to finding solutions to complex problems and developing system change. As a Transition Specialist for nine High Schools and the Community Immersion program with the Oakland Unified School District she provides students opportunities to pursue higher education and/or employment pursuits to maximize functional independence. She was a sole practitioner for many years providing psychotherapy and counseling within a variety of mental health and physical rehabilitation facilities, involving disability rights. Corigan Malloy is pursuing her Doctorate in Educational Leadership.  hasbeen an educator for 22 years she is currently teaching elementary school inWest Oakland.  She has presented at workshops in the Oakland Unified School district, focusing on classroom management and Common Core Math.  Shealso taught elementary, adult education and community college classes in NewYork, Hawaii, Georgia.  She is a published author.  She is deeply committed to the ideal of socially just education. Bryan Moore is currently in his seventh year as a supporting team member and instructional assistant in the Aspergers Inclusion Program at Skyline High School. He completed coursework for BS in psychology at Colorado State University. Seven years of experience working with child sex offenders and a one-to-one aid for children with autism. Advocate for joy, promoter of fun and enjoyable classroom environments for kids.Ian Patton is an Intervention Specialist in the Asperger's Inclusion Program at Skyline High School.  He has 10 years of experience serving the educational andsocial-emotional needs of at-risk youth and students on the Autism Spectrum.Ian firmly believes in power of experiential and project based learning.Michelle Remy is a parent, educator and writer living in Oakland. She has worked with children and youth as a mentor, coach, teacher, camp director and after school program director. She has been both a parent and teacher at a successful progressive, K-8 project-based charter school and currently works in a high school Aspergers' Inclusion Program providing behavioral and academic support.Lydia Ropp has taught at Skyline High School for 7 years, teaching Art the private sector for 20. She is an active participant in the Education in the Digital Age/ Capstone project to teach Government through civic action. Has completed all course work for a Masters in Education Administration and completing research on restructuring school bureaucracy; radically restructure the organization of the learningenvironment to raise the rigor and realism of educational experiences.Heidi Neipris Wexler has a Masters Degree in Counseling Psychology from California Institute of Integral Studies. She has worked with youth and older adults across the life spectrum weaving writing, cooking, and creative arts along with a personal passion for optimal health into our program for the past seven years, while helping to raise two teenagers of her own.Mark Greyland has synesthesia, his work is dedicated to the blending of sensory stimuli with music and animation and displayed at ComicCon 2013 and in local galleries. Mark is also an ISTQB Certified Software tester for companies Xerox and Intel. Network Administrator has made him deeply interested in digital technology in art and music and in the creative lives of children including Marks twin son who is on the Autism Spectrum. Mark is the author of Stringbreaker's notebook, a guitar technique manual and has for NZ Musician Magazine. How Else We Can Use Your Help!Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:
Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!
And that’s all there is to it.

story:
**THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT LAST YEAR! We reached and surpassed our initial goal!!! NOW WE KNOW WE CAN DO  DO IT FOR 2015! **


This Christmas most of us will be enjoying the happiest time of the year, with plenty of food, friends and gifts. Sadly without our help many people around the world aren't able to do so. Some time ago, we (a small group of kindred spirits) decided to pull our efforts and make a difference in our "backyard", the community of malnourished children and their families of the Centro de Nutricion Niño Jesus, in the outskirt of Santo Domingo. We need your help to share the gift of nutrition this season! 

Short Summary

We have been raising funds and supporting the center for more than 10 years. This center is a non-profit institution established in 1990 by the Sisterhood of Mary of Schoensttat. The center feeds and takes care of 120 children. Its main purpose is to offer health, hygiene, education and nutritional services to malnourished children (ages 0-5 years) of the impoverished community of La Victoria, north of Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic.

A couple of years back the sisters shared with us the set backs the children would face on Christmas break (the center closes for 2 weeks during Christmas). Most of the children’s families do not have enough to eat. The children come back from break thinner and with their immune system weakened. So we decided to focus on two important objectives, providing a Christmas Nutritional Care Package for the children and their family, and filling up the center’s Milk Bank for the upcoming year.

With your donations we will be helping 120 families have a happy Christmas!

What We Need & What You Get

Lets break this down for you folks in more detail:

Christmas Nutritional Care Packages: We are going to prepare  120 Christmas Nutritional Care packages that help feed the children and their families for the 2 weeks (Dec 22-Jan 7) while the center is closed. Any donation amount is appreciated and encouraged. Each package costs US$25.00 (EU 20.00) to prepare, if you would like to donate an entire package we would be incredibly grateful!

The Christmas Nutritional Care it includes 

  • 2 pounds of Fortified Oatmeal
  • 4 pounds of Rice
  • 4 pounds of kidney beans
  • 2 boxes of spaghetti
  • 4 cans of sardines
  • 4 cans of spam
  • 1 pound of Fortified Cocoa Powder
  • 2 packages of diapers  
  • A small goodie bag of sweets
  • One fun Christmas toy per child

The Milk Bank: We need to fill up the center’s Milk Bank for the upcoming year, this money will be used to buy supplies for the center such as:

  • Milk
  • Nutritional Supplements
  • Soap and Detergents
  • Diapers
  • Medication that is not subsidized by the state
  • Supplies and goodies for the Children's Holiday Party

The perks you will receive

 -HOLIDAY XMAS CARD: Donations from USD $10.00 and up will receive a beautiful digital Holiday greeting from all the children at the Center.

-FROM U WITH LUV: XMAS CARE PAC: Donations of USD $25.00 (EU20.00) provide an entire Christmas Care Package!! We will send you a digital photograph of your personalized Christmas Nutritional Care Package and the child for whom you have been Santa Claus!

-Your PLACE at our Tree: Donations of USD $100.00 and up will grant you a place in our donor Xmas tree at the center! We will send you a digital picture of your Xmas ornament and its placement on our tree AND a Fun video of the Center’s Xmas Party!

The Impact

The truth is that for less than what we spend at dinner in a restaurant; we are able to make a huge difference in the lives of these children and their families.

Malnourished children experience developmental delays, weight-loss and illness as a result of inadequate intake of protein, calories and other nutrients. Malnourishment can greatly compromise a child’s immune system, making them more susceptible to infectious diseases. It not only impacts growth in the short term, but can also limit total bone growth. Malnutrition negatively effects brain development, causing delays in motor and cognitive development.

These Christmas Care Packages will help prevent that the children of the center loose the gains that they have achieved during their time there. It will ensure that they and their families have enough nutrients during break, and it will share the joy of this special time of the year.

We will be giving the gift of sustained nutrition and health this Christmas to these kids and their families. Lets reach our target and give them a happy and healthy Xmas!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just aren’t able to make financial contributions, but that doesn't mean they can’t help!

Please help us get the word out!  Share this campaign with as many people as you can. Talk about us on Twitter, Instagram, Facebook, SnapChat,  Snail Mail, Whatsapp… you get the gist…

HELP US GIVE THESE KIDS A GREAT XMAS GIFT

If you happen to be in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic and want to become a part of our team of volunteer packers contact us and we will let you know what you can do to help!

story:
Short Summary

BEST Rome is a crew of enthusiastic engineering students which aim to organise an unforgettable and completely free of charge Autumn Course on technology for 25 participants from all over the Europe. We strongly believe in something more than just regular studying and we deem in free education.

In October we will be holding "Game of Drones", a course at the Engineering faculty of Sapienza - University of Rome about the amazing world of Drones, about the technology and success behind it. With the help of world-wide known professors and partners we are organizing a 7 day course with lectures and practical sessions.

Organisers and the last year's participants

What We Need & What You Get

Rome is not the most inexpensive city in Europe and the financial support from our faculty is getting weaker and weaker. The difficulties of the economy at the moment is not helping the drone uprising industry and is giving us a hard time to raise funds for our Autumn Course. That's why we NEED YOUR help.

The money we will raise will go strictly to organise the logistic part of the course: accommodation for 25 persons (hostel), public transport tickets and food and drinks (3 meals per day with at least one hot meal) and small gadgets.

Moreover, for our participants we designed an awesome Game of Drones t-shirt, which will be yours choosing one of our perks!

The Impact

The spirit of our association is that incoming students should not ever pay for our courses. 25 drone lovers from all over Europe, students like us,  will come to our magnificent city to learn more about this technology hot topic.

We like to have as much diversity as possible on our courses and a deep fusion of knowledge and culture. 

Our mission is developing students through empowered diversity. We firmly believe that the key of a successful development of engineering students runs in this direction. 

Every course we organize terminates with a formal examination and certificate is provided to the ones who pass. University credits can be gained at each student home university and enrich participant’s collage CV. Above all Game of Drones will give them an incredible study and lifetime experience.

During one of the lectures

Some of our last year participants on Piazza Navona during the city rally

Risks & Challenges

We are a ONG of engineering students who dedicate their free time to off-school projects for absolutely no money. We are volunteers searching for a more proactive and productive student life. Our name is BEST Rome (Board of European Students of Technology Rome). We are a non-profit organisation and members before us have been organising courses like this one for past 20 years. We try to create wonders and unforgettable memories with little money and hard work.

Closing ceremony participants & organisers

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you for checking out this page. Please, consider donating and making this a lifetime experience for us and for the people to come. We sincerely hope that you gonna like our ideas and our project and support us!

If you can't donate we would appreciate that you share and talk about our idea. Spread the word about geeks and nerds all around the world!

If you are a business, a Drone or in general a technology enthusiast we are more than open for any kind of collaborations. Make us fly!

story:
Short Summery 

Lama means ‘WHY’ in Hebrew. My name is Hila Ben Gera, I founded Lama Theater Company in 2014 with a goal to create theater that constantly raises questions and encourages new and bold writing/directing from within the nation and around the world. We are a nonprofit company, located at The Kraine Theater, NYC.  Our purpose is to create work that is socio-culturally impactful. We give interdisciplinary artists a platform to create risk taking and thought provoking theater that will inspire the audience to question the world around them and by that to create a community that enlivens our existence.

I had the privilege to volunteer at The Peace Project in Nicaragua in March 2015. I was teaching English through theater to local children. It was one of the most exciting experiences of my life. I realized how magical art can be to children in their process of learning.

The Peace Project is a non­-governmental organization in Nicaragua and in the United States. It seeks to expand educational opportunities, encourage artistic expression and appreciation, and fosters environmental stewardship for the communities surrounding Laguna de Apoyo, Nicaragua.

I was so inspired by The Peace Project mission and the community that I’ve asked Kenneth (Founder of The Peace Project) to collaborate and create a time and space for Lama to bring sixteen professional artists from the US (including Lama‘s creative time) to live, create and volunteer with the local kids and community for 20 days! This year the theme we are going to explore is ‘Why Garbage?’

We received many submissions from writers, playwrights, musicians and poets. We have chosen a selective, excited and talented troupe eager to make a substantive contribution to the community via the Peace Project in Nicaragua from January 28th until February 18th.

The support, enjoyment and inclusion of the community are a big priority to Lama. We aim to give the community tools, knowledge and education through workshops in drama, movement, music and English, and base them around the theme ‘WHY GARBAGE?’. We want both artists and the community to mutually benefit from our time at the Peace project.


What We Need & What You Get

WHERE WILL THE DONATIONS GO?
The funds will be distributed as follows:
-Travel expenses.
-Materials for students from the local schools.
-Creative workshops (English, Movement, and Music.)
- Production costs: after 20 days, the artist’s creative workshops around the environmental awareness theme('Why Garbage') will lead to free performances of the artists and the children in front of the local community in Nicaragua.

DO WE GET TO SEE THE FINAL PROJECT?
You sure do!
We will be recording and documenting all outcomes and artistic development from this project with hopes to bring light to the Peace Project and the community by hosting a showcase event in NYC in March, 2016.

The Impact

The Peace project is a nonprofit organization that has inspired over 25,000 artists, donors, corporations, service businesses, art patrons and others in 70 countries to donate art, money, resources and time which have helped The Peace Project transform tens of thousands of lives worldwide. Its ambitious objective is to change what people think about change. The Peace Project’s heartfelt belief is that people working in unison, in community, are the most powerful agents for change and we are extremely excited to be a part of their environment for 20 days to volunteer in the local community and make a change through the magic world of theater.

Risks & Challenges

At the moment, the chosen artists are struggling with the financial expenses, and taking time off from their jobs to be able to commit to this journey in Nicaragua.The high expenses can prevent this project from happening. Help us make this project a reality.

Marianna Staroselsky (Playwright. One of the resident artists, wrote:) “Garbage = a cesspool of misunderstandings between human beings, all the things we cut away to make reality “clearer” and more efficient for cognitive processing but often this process over-simplifies who we are to each other. So often we caricature and stereotype each other. Everything that means something (all those little pieces of identity and detail) might be lying there discarded -- the truths that matter, that thicken the complexity of who we are.”

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can contribute, Llamas all over the world will always protect you! 
  • If you cannot contribute, you can share our campaign with your friends!
Lama Theater Company is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a nonprofit arts service organizations. Donations for the charitable purposes of Lama Theater Company must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

contribute, Llamas all over the world will always protect you! 
If
you cannot contribute, you can share our campaign with your friends! 



Lama Theater Company is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a nonprofit arts service organizations. Donations for the charitable purposes of Lama Theater Company must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Midsummer Wakes on 9 July 2016

After last years successful  carnival, lots of people asked us, B arts, to repeat the event for communities in Newcastle under Lyme. 
So we talked to a few funders including, the Arts Council of England, who all thought it was a good idea and they gave us some money to make a carnival again this year.
This year we will be based in a shop in 60 Ironmarket, thanks to the support of the landlord, and there will be free drop-in family workshops on Saturdays: 18, 25 June and 2 July (10.30 -4).  In the workshops there will be opportunities for volunteers and community groups to create colourful carnival images and costumes, working with carnival artists from B arts.
We think Midsummer Wakes creates a fun celebration for families in Newcastle under Lyme, it gets people talking positively about the town, coming into the town centre and enjoying themselves.
This year we need a little bit more money to unlock the funds from the Arts Council of England. They need to see that people want this project to happen again and are willing to help out. 
We need to raise another £800, so can you help us?  
Being able to work with disadvantaged young people and families makes the carnival a richer and more inclusive event and without your money we won't be able to include as wide a range of groups.  
Please contribute what you can, if you can't then come to a workshop, or get involved on the day. We'd love to see you there, and thanks very much for reading this.
Lastly: please share this like mad on your Facebook, twitter or email. It takes a town to make a carnival!

story:
Hi!
I’m Signy Fridriksson.

I recently graduated with my MA in Counselling and Spirituality from Saint Paul University. I am about to start my private practice in counselling with a focus on Couples and Families.

Prior to my studies, I was a birth doula, accompanying moms and their partners during the birth of their child; a childbirth mentor, teaching birth preparation classes to help expectant parents conquer their fears and discover their strengths; and a relationship enrichment leader, helping couples build stronger relationships. Bettering people’s emotional lives has always been important to me! With my background, earning my MA was a natural next step to enable me to provide fuller and deeper support for couples and families.

As is quite common, I have ended my studies with a fair bit of student debt. In spite of that, I am still wanting to grow and improve! There are a couple of trainings that I would like to take to help me be the best counsellor I can be!

The first is a training with Stan Tatkin, founder of The Psychological Approach to Couple Therapy (PACT). PACT helps couples build secure-functioning relationships. Stan has written a couple of books - Wired for Love and Wired for Dating - and has a great CD set - Your Brain on Love. He is a wonderful teacher. PACT has proven successful at helping couples build and express their trust, caring and commitment for each other.

The second training is with The Gottman Institute. The Bringing Baby Home Program counters the sad statistics that 66% of new parents report a decline in relationship satisfaction and more than 50% of mothers have some symptoms of depression after giving birth. According to the Gottman Instutute research, parents who take the Bringing Baby Home classes do not experience the same decline in relationship satisfaction, and less than half the number of mothers showed signs of depression.

You can see why I am so excited about taking these trainings - These are the kinds of impacts I want to have with my clients!

I hope you will help me access these trainings! Between the tuition fees, travel and accommodations, each training will be about $2200 CND, so my funding goal is $4400 CND. I am already enrolled in the PACT Training, so the first $2200 I collect will go to pay for that training. If I receive more funds, the extra amount will go toward my registration and associated costs for the Bringing Baby Home Training.

Thanks so much for your support! Whether you give a financial gift ($5, $10, $20, $50, $100 or any amount you wish to contribute) or share my campaign with others, it means so much to me that you care!

Lots of love,
Signy

story:
Group Growing

Help us help each other to grow food to feed our communities. What we have been doing for the past few years is...

  • Teaching mushroom growing workshops. (For Free)
  • Sharing mushroom spawn (seed-stock). (For Free)
  • Sharing mushrooms and medicinal supplements. (For Free)
  • Sharing Fungal Cultures (For Free)
  • Starting and building mushroom farms for people and communities (For Free)
  • Sharing vegetable and flower seeds. (For Free)

 

            

We all have different experiences and skill sets. By teaching each other and working together we can attain results quicker and of a higher quality. Group Growing has helped thirteen communities build and establish Oyster and Lion's Mane cultivation facilities. These mushrooms will feed these communities as well as their larger local community.

 

                         

What We Need & What You Get

We need resources to build the infrastructure for growing mushroom farms.

We need the equipment and production supplies.

Please contribute now. You can receive the following rewards for you contribution...

  • Grow at home mushroom kits.
  • Workshops!
  • Grow at home videos.
  • A farm of your very own! Or a farm you can give to others!
  • T-shirts and wooden spinning mushroom tops.
  • Mushroom Chocolates.
  • Mushroom Culture Preservation explorer packs
  • Consultations
  • Sharondale Farm Teas

 

Think Global, Act Local

Group Growing teaches and advocates techniques that can work in any part of the world. Using local waste products as final substrates for growing mushrooms, we can provide top quality fungi for a fair price; eventually even FREE. We seek to put the production of spawn into the hands of local cultivators; creating closed loop sustainable practices.

 

                       

 

A small farm can be started (and sustained) in just one weekend

We recently started a mushroom farm for a couple of amazing glassblowing artists. They knew nothing about mushroom cultivation before we taught them.

                                     

We taught and trained them in simple oyster mushroom inoculation...

 

                                    

Sterilization and sanitary spawn expansion...

                                   

And then we played games... (next to a mini-greenhouse full of inoculated Lion's Mane, Reishi, and Oyster mushroom blocks.)

 

                                 

It did take a few weeks before to prepare all the spawn to have ready for the weekend. In just that weekend however, they were able to learn (and do!) everything required to sustain their tiny mushroom farm. They have since harvested and eaten the mushrooms, created their own spawn and inoculated their own blocks. They are now considering expanding to a full scale farm (because their guest room is often occupied). They know everything they need to run and sustain their own large farm now. We chat with them every week or so and they are still learning the intricacies and mastering the craft. 

You can get your own small scale farm weekend workshop by contributing to this campaign now at the "Tiny Farm Workshop Weekend" contribution level.

Risks & Challenges

Contamination is the biggest hindrance to any mushroom grower. We teach methods and procedures that reduce the risk of contamination. Attention to detail is what separates a great mushroom cultivator from average one. For amateur level cultivars we suggest beginning with oyster mushrooms and working up from there. 

Group Growing advocates using extremely low tech methods anyone can replicate at home. It's about feeding all of our families. Everyone cannot afford expensive sterile laboratories as you see some Group Growing members in below.

 

                         

Building Community leads to Economic Empowerment

The farm used to be a central part of the community; it fed its members. Now we use money at grocery stores to buy food, we simply hope was grown with care. In actuality those fruits and veggies burned a lot of fuel traveling the globe to arrive at your local store, But don't worry, all the nasty chemical bybroducts from refining that fuel is sprayed on those veggies as pesticides and herbicides. It's a win-win, lol, or is it kill-kill? Anyway, we don't go near that stuff, we are Group Growing. We use only organic and natural processes to grow mushrooms. We teach our farms to do the same.

What will we do with the money?

  • Buy our farms much needed infrastructure
  • Build a Mobile Mushroom Lab
  • Continue starting more farms
  • Continue sharing cultures, supplements and knowledge
  • Get help for our farmers
  • Host Free Fungi Feasts!

Mushrooms for Bees?! What?!

One of the cool things about Group Growing's network of farms is it enables us to research some cutting edge technologies.

Our Favorite long-term research and development projects include:

  • Growing Biodynamic Mushrooms
  • Creating a mushroom mycelium Bee Hive
  • Assessing mycoremediation efforts
  • and growing new species of mushrooms!

Other Ways You Can Help

Group Growing is a grassroots movement creating self-sustaining mushroom production to benefit communities. We believe mushrooms can complete the nutritional profile alongside vegetable farms and/or community gardens. We seek to divert waste streams into our processes as oyster mushrooms will eat virtually any ligno-cellulosic material. The end results are healthy, protein rich mushrooms and amazing soil ammendments that helps increase moisture retention; assisting any farm against drought. We are also planning to use extra spent substrate logs as bio-remediation buffers. Two of our more cutting edge research projects include mycelial bee hives as well as biodynamic mushrooms. Our network is being set up to run decentralized experiments for the benefit of humanity.

If you can't afford to contribute USD currency, you can help in other ways.

Email Team@GroupGrowing.com to get involved. 

You can also:

  • SHARE this campaign with your friends, family and coworkers. Tell them what mushrooms mean to you!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools! Share this campaign far and wide! 

Thanks! Much Love!

Group Growing makes growing mushrooms easy for toddlers and elders alike.

Using simple machines.

Living Simple Lives.

Helping Each Other.

We are all Brothers and Sisters, We are our brothers' keepers. Love!

story:
Short Summary

 We are a group of Arab-American students in Chicago who are trying to make the most out of an opportunity to teach English overseas. Last year some of us had the opportunity to go down to Gaziantep to teach in a summer school for Syrian students. Many refugees in Gaziantep have been deprived of an education for several years. Within days, 200 Syrian students of all ages had enrolled in our course, free of charge. This is a testament to the great need for educational opportunities amongst the Syrian refugee population. 

Inspired by these experiences, we have come together to set up a program to help displaced Syrian students find academic opportunities by acquiring proficiency in English. By taking and passing the TOEFL exam, students can become eligible to apply to higher educational institutions and employment, thereby improving their station in life. The TOEFL exam can be a venue for social mobility for those that can afford it. For this reason, we've made it our mission to provide a TOEFL scholarship for 50 Syrian refugees. The TOEFL scholarship would include the fees for the TOEFL prep course, the TOEFL exam, and student expenses. Through these scholarships, we hope to empower Syrian refugees by allowing them to take charge of their lives and careers once more. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our mission is to raise money for a TOEFL scholarship fund so these displaced Syrian students can continue their education in Turkey. We have partnered with Zirve University to admit displaced students into a program that will cover the costs of their TOEFL exam and a 10 week prep course taught at Zirve by their bilingual instructors. Zirve has given us a discounted rate at $700 per student which includes student expenses and TOEFL test fees. Our goal is to award 50 scholarships at a total cost of $35,000.

We are optimistic that we can reach our goal of 50 scholarships but we will try to get as many as we possibly can. All donations go through AALIF, a 501(c)(3) certified organization whose donations are tax-deductible, before being used to pay Zirve University. Every $700 we get goes directly to reserving a seat for a displaced student at Zirve University. Because we are paying to cover the costs of the program, there is no upper limit to how many scholarships we can award. If we send one student or one hundred, we are still going to keep collecting.

If we do not reach our goal of 50 students we will award whatever scholarships we can. None of the funds raised ever go to any administrative or operational costs unrelated to the TOEFL classes. Money is deposited to Zirve University in increments of $700 to reserve individual seats. The seats we reserve remain saved for us until we have enough students to offer another course.

The Impact

Most of us are so affected by images of Syrians fighting for their mere survival that we forget that there are many different struggles the Syrian people face. Many of them are students who have left their families and have no idea what they are going to do next in life. That is a sentiment that I feel many of us can relate to.

We often worry about the fate of young Syrians in these dark times. By offering them alternatives to their current circumstances through education we are aiding them against the tide of uncertainty that pushes these students into the cycle of despondency.

It may not seem like much but many of us have spent months studying for a single exam that we think will determine our future. We have already awarded five scholarships to our former summer school students and they have successfully completed their prep course and taken their TOEFL exams. They are now working with educational institutions in America to try to get accepted into academic programs in the US. A single exam can make all the difference.

Risks & Challenges

Working to help displaced Syrians both within Syria and outside of it comes with the expected challenges of dealing with the results of a devastating conflict. Many organizations working to offer services to these Syrians must deal with various (and often opposing) authorities on both sides of the border while working in the midst of severe poverty and an unstable atmosphere.

Luckily for us, we already have good friends in Gaziantep who are willing to help us out. Between our affiliations with a local university and our contacts in the Syrian educational community we feel confident in our ability to offer a safe and resourceful environment for our students and teachers.

We have been working on these educational programs for over a year now and have learned how to avoid the common pitfalls that come with international aid work.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Even if you can’t contribute funds right now we’re sure you know someone who can. It takes no effort to put the word out online and you never know what a single plug can do.

And please stay updated with the program through our face book page!

story:
Hi you guys! As some of you may know, I currently attend the University of California Berkeley seeking a degree in Landscape Architecture. However, this spring there will be a momentary shift in where I receive my education. I will be studying abroad in Rome, Italy.

I do not usually talk about my background as a disadvantage on the grounds that it has helped me become the person I am today. However, growing up in Oakland, California is not the easiest experience that one can undergo. Consistent violence and underfunded schools were my biggest issues being raised in Oakland. However, I viewed these adverse conditions as a type of propellant to work hard for a better future for my family and I.

I have always sought after higher education. In high school, I envisioned going to school at UC Berkeley, but actually attaining a spot at Cal seemed like a far-fetched ambition. Through hard work and dedication, I was able to obtain a spot at Cal as an undergraduate, and since then I have pushed through my freshman year, and my first semester of my sophomore year. I am continuing to persevere as a student, and before all else as an individual.

I have enjoyed the studio courses that I have taken at UC Berkeley so far; they have allowed me to express myself through abstract projects that relate to Architecture. I am still yearning for knowledge

revolving around Landscape Architecture/Architecture. This trip to Italy will allow me to grasp a distinctive education that revolves around how Architecture differs in other surroundings outside of the United States.

I have never been outside of the United States, let alone California. I am beyond excited for this trip; however, studying abroad will take a toll on me financially. I receive financial aid, and I have worked on campus throughout the year to pay for my classes and personal expenses. I never choose to burden my parents with finances, as they have finances of their own. I want to make the most out of this once in a lifetime experience without having finances on the back of my mind. I know finances can add up quickly, especially around the holidays. Whether it is a large or small donation, any donation towards my trip abroad will be truly appreciated. I set my eyes on UC Berkeley when I was in high school, and I am still continuing to work hard to complete my undergraduate degree here at Cal. I now have my eyes set on Rome.

Once again, I would be more than thankful for any donations. Thank you for devoting your time to read a brief part of my life, and what is to come.

Best,

Hector Arvizu

However, I viewed these adverse conditions as a type of propellant to work hard for a better future for my family and I. 	I have always sought after higher education. In high school, I envisioned going to school at UC Berkeley, but actually attaining a spot at Cal seemed like a far-fetched ambition. Through hard work and dedication, I was able to obtain a spot at Cal as an undergraduate, and since then I have pushed through my freshman year, and my first semester of my sophomore year. I am continuing to persevere as a student, and before all else as an individual. 	I have enjoyed the studio courses that I have taken at UC Berkeley so far; they have allowed me to express myself through abstract projects that relate to Architecture. I am still yearning for knowledge revolving around Landscape Architecture/Architecture. This trip to Italy will allow me to grasp a distinctive education that revolves around how Architecture differs in other surroundings outside of the United States. 	I have never been outside of the United States, let alone California. I am beyond excited for this trip; however, studying abroad will take a toll on me financially. I receive financial aid, and I have worked on campus throughout the year to pay for my classes and personal expenses. I never choose to burden my parents with finances, as they have finances of their own. I want to make the most out of this once in a lifetime experience without having finances on the back of my mind. I know finances can add up quickly, especially around the holidays. Whether it is a large or small donation, any donation towards my trip abroad will be truly appreciated. I set my eyes on UC Berkeley when I was in high school, and I am still continuing to work hard to complete my undergraduate degree here at Cal. I now have my eyes set on Rome.	Once again, I would be more than thankful for any donations. Thank you for devoting your time to read a brief part of my life, and what is to come. Best,Hector Arvizu

story:
hello i am a single parent, i am asking for your support, I am a mother of 3 and have struggled with post-natal depression which has led me to find a deeper understanding of what this means and ways to support more women, when my second son was small I found myself in a very difficult place and life circumstances brought me to a place of struggle, and then when i had another child in a new relationship the depression came again. I am now reaching 2 years of breast feeding and looking after my dear children with all the challenges this has brought, it has also brought some deep healing. As a women and a mother i have reached that point where i need to give to myself.

 I started to meditate and my inner calling was loud and clear i needed to use my voice. while on this journey of healing i found pioneer Jill purse in sound healing and embarked on a weekend taster course, 6 years ago. Its called the healing voice, here is the link. http://www.healingvoice.com/workshops.htm

I left the course 5 years ago not realizing how much just the 2 days taster would impact me, not wanting leave and I new I had unfinished business, due to life circumstances i have struggled with communication and expressing myself, which has led to very unsuccessful relationships, now is my opportunity i am deeply called to continue on this journey.

 I have studied sound therapy with other people and over the years and have trained as a thereapist, but have found the effects of being on my own with the children  and the relationships i have failed at has led to me loosing confidence in myself and i feel this course would be a great time for me to revisit me as a women, and regain some self worth and confidence. I have regularly chanted this has brought me deep peace, although since my third child i have become more house bound and rarely get to do the things i have found have helped me in the past.

the only thing holding me back is finances, every penny counts so please even a dollar or a pound would begin my journey, i would love the support from any one who is able to help me continue on this beautiful journey of self discovery. with love and gratitude to one and all for any support given thanks xx

story:
Short Summary

You've all heard the stories of Rwanda.  Stories of suffering and pain, loss and death. Now I’m calling you to send a hope and making a small difference in the life of others, we’re not asking for University degree but for Skills Training in the sewing and Handicrafts production industry and for basic training in entrepreneurship.

 “The Survivors are not heroes because they escaped from death but rather because they can support the pain, and live with all of the consequences of Genocide”  “Le Livre d’Elise” E. Rida

 http://www.lesbelleslettres.com/livre/?GCOI=22510100614430&fa=description

My name is Elise Rida ,i was born in Rwanda . After lost my family during genocide when i was 10 ,I did not have hope , no one can give me hope , future has not sense for me , but when I had opportunity to get scholarship to study. It gave me the energy to work hard for change, ; it represented the return of confidence and hope , 

Twenty years after the genocide were for me twenty years of survival and reconstruction. "Around me are the widows, the orphans. The ground on which I walk has not dared him to drink the blood of the innocent. "Elise said in his book

 I obtained my bachelor's degree in Sociology in 2011, I also had the opportunity to do a training course of leadership Development the "Peace Through Business Program" in Texas, the USA. I have a shop of Handcrafts in Kigali/Rwanda .In 2014 ,i published my Book called "Le Livre d' Elise ,les Belles Lettres ,Paris,2014

I became who I am because of support of others, so it is my time to give my help to others, there more orphans and widows who have not had the chance like me I believe that it is time to give back to the society but i need your support .

“We never knew adolescence; we became the forced parents of our little brothers and Sisters but also of ourselves.”  Elise said in his book ,Le livre d'Elise

This situation become both teenagers and parents, most of them have not had the opportunity to follow their studies and have the education, that is why training in sewing for widows and orphans and weaving for older women who can not learn sewing .

we started our activities there is already one month with 15 widows/orphans for the sewing and 6 of the oldest widows for weaving of the traditional baskets , 

The beautiful Rwandan handcrafted baskets have been a part of the Rwanda culture ,These baskets are made from natural raw materials that all can be found growing in Rwanda – sisal fibers, sweet grass, banana leaves and raffia.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $ 6200 USD to continue our activities and to make our dream a reality .

Your funding will help us:

  • - The purchase of sewing machines

    - The purchase of fabric of learning and of material

  • Every dollar is important because it represents a return to the hope for these young people and these  women. The more our project collects funds, the more we can help them

  • The Impact

    "Where there is Hope ,there is Power"! , this is first impact of this project , represent the return of confidence and hope.

    it will have a considerable impact on the Socio-economic life , allowing it through employment generated a financial autonomy, an independence which will lead the widows and the orphans towards a better future.

story:
Harriet Tubman Students Need Your Support

Harriet Tubman Democratic High School is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit school serving mostly low-income families in and around Albany, NY. Harriet Tubman enrolls many students who were drop-outs or considered at-risk, and offers a safe and diverse community for all youth. We receive no public funds and over half of our students have always received scholarships. For the past three school years, over 90% of our students received significant tuition assistance, with over 70% qualifying for full tuition coverage. This is why we are turning to you for help.

  

Students need our services, but we are struggling to provide them because we lack the funding. Every year our school works hard to raise the money needed to sponsor every child-in-need. We need to raise the last $5,500 (of our $40,000 goal) by July 31. The $3,000 goal of this Indiegogo campaign will help us to raise the final funds we need for 2015!

You Can Help These Children Graduate

With your support, we can continue to serve children in desperate need of our help. 79% of Harriet Tubman graduates have gone on to attend college or career training programs and 97% have been successful there. The unique philosophy of the Harriet Tubman program allows us to meet the particular challenges children face and helps them earn a high school diploma.

Over eight years ago, Harriet Tubman Democratic High School opened its doors to offer students a learning environment that responds to the unique needs of each child. Our student-centered school engages every child in their own learning process with the guidance and support of teachers dedicated to their academic and personal development. Visit here for a detailed presentation of our program.

You Will be Helping Children Like...

Sakeem first came to Harriet Tubman as a 17 year old 9th grader, having dropped out after failing multiple times. Sakeem was extremely self-conscious about his age and lacked the confidence needed to succeed academically. His common  refrain: “I can’t do it.”


Yet Sakeem had a passionate desire to earn his high school diploma, and the staff recognized this. They committed their time to building a trusting relationship with him, and provided the mentorship and individual instruction he needed.  Through the safe and supportive community of Harriet Tubman, Sakeem was empowered to open up and find the confidence to make the major changes he wanted in his life. After spending only one year at Harriet Tubman, Sakeem passed his first high school state assessment test – ever – an exciting personal accomplishment. Now, after voluntarily spending two of his summers on school work, Sakeem is on track to graduate this spring.

Other Ways You Can Help

Your contribution towards our Student Support Fund, and your help in sharing this campaign, will provide support to cover costs to which most of our student families cannot contribute. We strive to  create a learning environment that meets every child’s needs, and your support will help make that possible.

While large donations are helpful, a great number of small donations will also get us to our goal — every bit helps!

If you are unable to make a contribution at this time, please consider helping us spread the word to other potential donors. Greater recognition for our campaign will go a long way to helping us reach out goal!

Challenges

Harriet Tubman does not receive any government funding. Yet with the growing number of students coming to us from low-income families, our revenue balance has shifted dramatically away from tuition-paying students. We require support from individuals in the wider community if the school is to continue to serve this population by helping them graduate high school.

Nationwide, people are realizing that there are many children who simply cannot learn in traditional schools. This is particularly true for students from low-income families who cannot afford to pay for the individual extra help of a tutor or small classrooms in a private school. The drop-out rate is alarmingly high, especially for low-income students of color. Equal access to all educational opportunities is beneficial to our entire community, as it allows our youth to support themselves through better employment and encourages them to make other positive life choices.
 

Our experience tells us that many children need small, community-based schools such as Harriet Tubman Democratic High School. For those who want to encourage the movement of non-traditional schools, or democratic education in particular, consider the power of helping Harriet Tubman demonstrate how alternative educational philosophies provide quality education to every child, from all walks of life.
